element_texts.text: Completed

Topsham Dec. 13th, 1846
Dear Mother,

    I received your excellent and most welcome letter yesterday.  I had been expecting a letter for a good while, in fact had got entirely out of patience of waiting, and three or four days before had written again to Milo, which it seems however you had not received when you wrote.  It must have been not far off though.  It seems you had quite a Thanksgiving at Milo after all.  I did not know whether the boys were going up or not.  I wanted much to go home, probably should if I had not been quite so poorunderlined.  However, now I find I have go to go on to Yale College, it is perhaps better, for now  I can have a vacation.  Next week. I guess I shall start Monday Dec. 21st, and go right on to Yale by Rail Road shortest route, be there Wednesday perhaps Thursday  also and get back the best way I can.  Almeda is in Boston at that time I will make arrangements to stop and call upon her.  I suppose likely the shortest route from Boston
Completed

will be by the way of Worcester and Springfield, & Hartford railroads.  How far would that be from Royalston & thereabouts?  Would it not be a nice plan, if I could only have a fortnight's vacation in stead of a week, and (a much more important "if") if I only had a little money of my own to spend, for me to visit some of the folks there?  You ask why I go to Yale.  It is to be a sort of a Convention, a great meeting of DKE Greek letters from different Institutions.  I am to represent Old Bowdoin there.  It will be a great time,  I assure you.  "A real high old time" as my fellow boarder the "Capting" Merrill would say.  It appears that Lucy is to be at Bangor this winter.  I am really glad of it:  that is if you can get along without her at home.  I think it is just exactly what she needs.  What sort of a chance will she have to get into Society there?  I think she ought to write to me long before this time.  It is long since I have heard a word from her.  She does not write so well as she need to.  I have an idea to go to Royalston & Warwick, but I suppose it will not do.  What sort of a thing is that little penny?  as good as she was last spring?  You know she is a real favorite of mine.  I want you should do really well by her.  Do you not like her better than little James?  I think though that he is a good little fellow; the best of the lot of them.
Completed

It is said that an arrangement has been on is being entered into, by the which this Institution of our Bowd Coll. is to be made a thoroughly Orthodox Orth underlined Institution.  The Board of Trustees & Overseers you know have been partly Unitarians, and the College party under their influence.  This is to be given up.  The Unitarians have agreed to sign off somehow.  The influence of my good friend Mr Wheeler, the U. clergyman to Topeham, the father of my little brother Charley, has been beneficial to that effect.  He says he is satisfied with one Unitarian College in N. E. (Harvard you know) is willing this should be under control of the Orthodox, only let it be liberal and give all denominations a fair chance.  I guess all the Unitarians agree to sign it except old Dr. Nichols of Portland who is rather offish.  The Orthodox on their part agree to get up $50,000.00 for the College within two years, to finish off the Chapel, perhaps endow a new Professorship.  Prof Upham I guess carries it: is very anxious for it: gives $5000.00 himself, perhaps more.  I expect Prof Upham is rather wealthy:  he has made a great deal by his books, is writing all the time, makes one or two thousand dolls. per year copy rights.  This Dec. 16th is our college examination day.  I went on before breakfast & passed firstrate in Astronomy.  let the rest wait till next spring.  I expect I shall feel quite relieved at having no more going to Coll before breakfast.  Next week vacation too.  By the way I had almost a touch of rebellion in my school yesterday.  It is a very bad school, and I
Completed

have before had occasion to threshunderlined a few and even turn out one or two.  Yesterday a case of disobedience underlined etc.  Attempted discipline, and there was resistance, refusal to submit.  I took the chap by the collar, as he raised his fists to defend himself, rapped him a few over head ears & said fists, put my boot toe against his foot, and let him fall pretty heavily upon the floor once or twice, then put him in his seat, and there he has behaved very decently since. More, while correcting him, half a dozen other chaps, got up & said "That's enoughunderlined"!  Therefore I threshed him a little longer, and then gave them a pretty serious lecture.  There is about the worse set of fellows among them that I ever saw any where.  One of them weighs 214 lbs. too.  However, they are somewhat afraid of me!  I do not know as I shall know where to find Almeda if she is in Boston.  I start Mond 21st. In great haste, just going out to spend evening. Do write to me soon & often. Aff. I. S. M.
Completed

Topsham Dec. 27th, 1846
Dear Mother
It is not long since I wrote to you I believe, only just before my journey, and since I have heard from you:  but I supposed you would like to hear from my adventures; and I should think as you are most all alone, your children gone away, that you would feel sort of lonely and like to receive letters -- just as I do.  So I will write again.  My Journey -- I started by stage Dec 20th Sabbath Eve at 10 1/2 oclock.  (By starting then I could be in Boston 1/2 a day to see Almeda; if I waited till morning, I must go straight underlinedthroughunderlined to get to New Haven in season.  Got to Portland at 3 A.M.  Got into the Cars at 7 1/2 A.M.  Upper Route for Boston, arrived there at 12 1/2 P. M.  Found Almeda & children all well Sissy getting fat again very fast, just been vaccinated &c.  Doctor charged her nothing, only 1.00 vaccination  Going to Sutton soon, waiting for letter from Joseph.  Called with Almeda at Mrs. Child's, and at Mr. Caleb Metcalf's Allen St.  Mr M unwell Rheumatic Fever &c.  Tuesday Rail Road to Worcester, to Springfield, to Hartford, to New Haven, where arrived 4 1/2 P.M.  quite a long ride for one day.
Completed

New Haven is very pleasant place, must be delightful in the summer season; beautiful buildings and abounding in trees, Colleges are a great affair about fourfold of poor Bowdoin and all so wealthy there too. Societies so wealthy, Hall etc. fitted up at an expense to be reckoned at thousands,

  I staid at New Haven one day & two nights. Attended a great meeting of D.K.E. then. After business transactions etc. etc. A great dinner at Midnight, get up on the greatest scale you ever saw, courses by the dozen all kinds of game and fish, delicacies of all sorts etc. Bill of fare half as long as a man;s arm.

Toasts, speeches, and songs, jokes etc. in abundance,. No drinking of any thing ardent, true DKE!!! 

 In the morning took the Cars again, Worcester at 4 1/2 P.M. Found Cousin Caleb B. Metcalf there. He has Mastership in one of the Public Schools there, Salary 1000 per year. Has bought him a fine house, I should think likely he has a fine sort of wife, a New Haven lady, daughter of a Professor there. Has no Children.  Stopped with him over night. Went to Lyceum Lecture by Rev. Dr. Wayland, President of Brown University, R.F. Subject Patriotism.
 Got to Boston 9 or 10 AM next morning. Christmas day had to make the children. Christmas gifts.etc. They are going to Sutton Monday 28th. All very well.
  Found by C.B. Metcalf's direction Cousin Enoch Metcalf  He has lately returned from St. Louis Missouri. has one child born to a Missourian: is temporarily engaged in a dry goods store at 339 Washington Street.
Completed

What sort of a man is Chauncey Chase. I did not like his appearance much. I was there at Supper Monday. I do not know as he hardly spoke to me at all. Mrs. Chase seems a very pleasant woman. I concluded Mr. Chase did not want me there if he did Almeda. Mrs. Chase invited me to stop there, but I went down to the U. L. Hotel, paid one dollar for lodging & breakfast. Rates at New Haven the same. $2,00 per day for board.
I started from Boston 2 1/2 P.M. RailRoad Lower route, by R.R. & Stage arrived at Brunswick Friday night at two or three oclock in the morning, and then slept till near noon, Saturday.
Had quite a journey, pleasant one generally somewhat tiresome, up so much nights. Expenses in all amounted to some $25,00 or $30.00 dollars. Part at least however will be refunded to me, in the spring.
Found here a letter from Lucy, no very late news. She seems to be enjoying herself and doing well I should think. Most anxious about your getting along alone.
I dread awfully to go into my school again however, the worst things must have an end.
I do not know as there is any thing in this letter worth sending, but perhaps you will like to hear of my journey. I hope you will write soon and often. Your Aff. Son, I.S. Metcalf
Almeda is full of plans for getting up a school or a boarding house or something
Completed

I.S. Metcalf
Feb. 28 '47

                                                                                                                          Bowd. Coll. Feb. 28th. 1847

Dear Mother,  

               I received your last letter, a few days since and much rejoiced was I thereat I assure you. I had begun to get tired of writing so long, near five weeks since I wrote last. However, it seems you waited to announce the wedding. Well I am glad to hear of it, but sorry and some vexed that I cannot be there for the interesting occasion. I had a great mind to start right off and go, but I suppose it would not do at all: even one week less of these lectures, to say nothing of the absoluteness of the "pecuniary negative."
 I suppose that at this time I am writing you there together, the girls, perhaps the boys too, returned home, and all enjoying yourselves finely.
 If I were ever in the habit of being otherwise than contented, and happy, in spite of fortune & circumstances, I really do not know but I should be, or want to be, 'homesick.' However, not being able to do as I said, I must do as I can, that is, if I can!
 I am glad that Charles has sold the colt, though I seem to think he ought to have brought a higher price than ,75,00  It seems hay is very low there. How much had Chas. to sell? If he
Completed

only had abundance of grain now, it would be worth while, wouldn't it? how much the United States are being enriched by this Flour business. It is horrible though to think of the Starvation in Ireland & other Countries of Europe.

  I see it started in a speech made in Fanuel Hall at a great 'Irish Relief Meeting' for subscriptions to send to Ireland, that every barrell of Flour sent to the poor of Ireland would preserve a human life! only think of it!
 My health is very good indeed, I gained 6 or 7 lbs. in weight in a fortnight after my school closed. I weight now upwards of 170 lbs. rugged and hearty as you please. and my whiskers the envy of half my class to boot!
 As for hurting myself at study, I guess there is no danger of that. I have already 'made up' all my last term's studying, and passed examination in them, the last yesterday. For the regular studies of my class, I do not have to study much, only a steady routine of lectures & recitations. I spend a great part of my time in reading nowadays.
 Our studies this year do not require a great deal of time. the lectures & the readings are the most important. 

[upside down]What should you think of my starting right off before the work is out, to take an Academy in New Hampshire for six months, then come back Commencement week, pass Examination, and take my degree? I some expect the chance,  and I could do it. I cannot get a 1st Oration if I stay. I couldn't take anything else. Most lost would be reading, that I could do after graduating, and how shall I have money. I may go. I.S.
Completed

Orono Me. March 17th, 1847 

Dear Mother, 

                 I do not know whether you have heard of my recent whereabouts, or whether this letter may take you entirely by surprise. However, Here I am, at Orono, or as I suppose it is more frequently called Lower Stillwater, about seven miles from Bangor, comfortably established, boarding at what is called a "werry nice place", at Dr. Ricker's, and teaching a great "High School." High School, both as being Up Stairs, and as having a high teacher, just from old Bowdoin, and an abundance of high scholars, or those who I suppose think themselves such. 
 I decided to come here last Friday March 12th, just before noon, started at 6 six P.M. by stage, at Portland Augusta, at 12 P.M. till 9 A.M. Saturday. By Mail Stage to Bangor, where I arrived at 8 1/2 P.M. and remained until 4 P.M. Monday March 15th. 
 I can assure you, or you can well imagine that I wanted to go up to Milo dreadfully, but could in no manner attain to it, as I was already one day behind my time, and if I remained even a single day longer, should probably have lost the whole concern of my school.
Completed

If I could only have known that I was coming this way, or thought of it a week sooner, I should have started in season to have made a visit to Milo, and been present upon the "Momentous Occasion" as Joseph calls it. Anne, Joseph and Eliab, I found just returned from Milo, I spent part of the Sabbath with Joseph, part with Anne and the night with Eliab, and Monday forenoon in loafing about at Joseph's & Eliab's stores, at Anne's schoolroom, and called at Nat. Harlow's, James P. Veazie's, and Mr Pomroy's. I came up here Monday P.M. and found the people extremely glad to see me, I suppose having feared they had lost their 'Master.' I began school. Tuesday Morning with 44 scholars, in the afternoon 46, and today upwards of 50. I have $3,00 per quarter, $,25 per week, or $1,00 per month for each scholar, My board costs $2,00 per week, other expenses of room, if I have to pay any rent, wood &, probably amount to $,50 per week, all $10,00 per month. So that if I average 40 scholars, I shall clear $30,00 per month, if 50 scholars which seems more at least probable, I should clear $40,00 per month. $100, in two and a half months, which is all the time I intend to remain here, As for security, it is said there is not one not as good & as pure as can be; besides at the last of May, when I shall get through, every man's pocket here is full of Cash
Completed

I like the appearance of people here much, so far, and they were spoken of very highly to me beforehand, by Wm. A. Pond, who taught a town school here just last Winter, and others.  The Scholars appear first rate; many of them are quite forward, and all seem well disposed. Last Evening I was invited in to Squire Wilson's, who was one of the projectors of the school. found the Congregationalist Choir, quite a large proportion of them I recognized as my scholars, and about as good looking a set of young person as one often sees.
                                            __________________

The next thing - I meaned it the first thing is.
How is that Sister Lucy?  I was pained to learn on arrival at Bangor that she had been unwell, and was not yet wholly recovered. How I do want to see her, as well as Dear Mother! I suppose I shall not be able to go to Milo until my school is through, last of May. but if Lucy returns to Bangor, I think I shall slope thither as soon as possible.
My best compliments etc.  etc, to the Bride and Bridegroom. Should much admire could I be there etc.  However "I'm coming", if nothing happens. Has Miss Quimby returned to Bangor? If not, Love of I.S. Metcalf etc.!
And now do, for pity's sake, let me hear from you, and that soon, and frequently.  Lucy, Lucy, If you have not given up writing altogether, do write to me.  In haste,  Good bye

                                                                I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Orono. April 4th, 1847
Mother,
That word; someone has said, I think it was that noble souled Lovejoy who was martyred at Alton, Illinois; that word needs no "Dear" before it. It expresses all without. 
I received letters from you and Lucy about a week ago; and much good they did me too. It seemed almost an age since I had heard from you. I had heard though to be sure by the boys at Bangor, whom I saw the day they left Milo, after the wedding. But then, you know, if I could not go to see "Mother & Lucy", I wanted at least to receive letters form them.
However, those letters were exactly what I had been aching for, for two long weeks; and you know that time always seems longer, when one is in a new place, before getting much acquainted; especially if one does not hear at all from former acquaintances; and I had been here almost a fortnight before I hear a single word from Milo, or from my other home & Mother's "Old Boudoir", where I had left many things from which I was anxious to hear from. 
If I thought that Lucy @, or would be a Bangor, I think I should go down there Fast Day.
Completed

You can hardly imagine how impatient I am to be able to go to Milo; At first I hardly knew as I should make out to keep up any degree of patience, but I begin to get a good deal interested, and to like my situation very much. I have got one of the very best and very pleasantest schools that ever was seen. I have about forty five scholars, and most of them very good ones, some very forward. About twenty of them are young ladies grown up, and such are altogether the best scholars generally, if one knows how to get along with them just right. They are easiest to govern, that is, if they need any governing; have a much better sense of propriety than young men generally, less of that stubborn independence in wrong oftener than right, which leads young men and their teachers into so much trouble. They are also easier to interest in studies or anything good, though perhaps to be fare, less likely to retain an interest if once excited, but with less to distract the mind. Most of my best classes are mostly young ladies. Another thing will perhaps amuse you -- my school is closed every day with singing! Pretty well, considering my musical capacities, is it not? The young ladies do it entirely among themselves, and it succeeds finely. Some eight or ten of them, are superior singers, the best part of two or three village choirs. I think it is a fine thing for the school, and pleases the scholars finely. It tends to cultivate and strengthen a good feeling among them.
Completed

It will certainly be extremely convenient for me if Charles can furnish me with some seventy five or one hundred dollars in June or July. That amount at least I must have from some source, in addition to what I shall obtain here; and I rather think, as you say, that I ought to have it from Milo, from the Old Farm. There is certainly property enough there in some shape. It is generally considered that a young man does pretty well, what indeed very few indeed do, if he educates himself liberally by his own exertions, or even mostly; even if he has a few hundred dollars help from some benevolent society. At any rate, it is not generally expected that a young man do more, if his relatives are in any sort of comfortable living circumstances. Now, since I was twenty, or about twenty one years old, I earned one year some more than one hundred dollars in cash, from which I certainly never received anything to help about going to College; and did one stout summer's work, or from Jan. to Sept. and much of the time through summer more work than a common man does or ought to do), on, and about the Old Farm there; before I thought of going to College. Then the year before I entered College, at Foxcroft, in the Academy & Village School, I guess I did as much as pay all my expenses. When I entered College, I had just twenty dollars. Mrs. Childs sent, have received some little from her since: besides that extremely little. It is curious how well I have got along: how favorable circumstances & Providence have been. Since entering Coll. I guess I have earned $400, besides keeping my Class
Completed

I suppose likely, in the peculiar circumstances, I hardly know why it should be, but suppose it is so, that it would or will be difficult for Charles, or any body else to furnish me with the money this summer. I suppose too that I could hire the money perhaps. I guess I could find those who would hire it tome. Guess old Frost in Topsham would, perhaps somebody in Bangor would; perhaps the Colburns here in Orono would; and, if I have my health and strength, and God blesses me as he has done, I could soon earn money and pay it. But, then, I am twenty five years old already; the most valuable portion of my life is fast passing away; and I ought not to be obliged to spend the prime of my strength, physical or intellectual, in some temporary employment to earn money to pay debts!
Still, all that, one way or the other, does not trouble me much. I can earn money any time, or do without. What does trouble me, is -- What shall I do in the world? I ought to have some fixed object in view to lend all my energies towards. What shall it be? You might say the ministry-- but I am not fit for it, and in more respects than one or two; should not be successful in it, in any respect. I think I might be successful as a Physician or Surgeon; that my mind would be fitted for it, etc. perhaps. But it is by far the most expensive of all professions, to study as I should want to. I would not be such a Doctor as Dr. Kimball, for instance, I would rather be a day laborer I think. Besides, I might not be able to convince myself sufficiently of the the truths on which the science of medicine is founded in order ever to enjoy myself in it. Then, it would take three or four years of study, and then years -- years -- no one knows how long, before one could be started, enough to establish himself in life; and I am 25!
Completed

I would, for the first thing, throw myself towards the mighty West, into the almost boundless Wisconsin or Iowa, or even across the continent, beyond the eternal bulwark of the mountains, into the New World of Oregon or California, there to hew out for myself, in some way, or in some path (in a New World there are always ways & paths enough); a name and an inheritance among the sons of men, a place to employ, for the good of myself and my fellow beings, the "one talent" that my God has given me: I would do this, I say, if it were not, that I like not, myself to separate myself, thus so greatly from those to whom God and nature have bound me by the ties of birth & affection. As Joseph wrote to me once, if Relatives and Friends were given to us as blessings, we ought not, rashly at least, to throw them away, or throw ourselves from them. But in New England prospects are certainly slim, in almost any path of life, for Young Men of Moderate Abilities, ? all the tastes & habits of educated life.
What shall I do -- I cannot well be a Physician; I am not fit for a Minister; I should probably starve to death as a lawyer; and I see no chance of getting an office!
You say you are going to be lonely there after Lucy is gone. Why need you to be? I expect you will fret yourself merely because you do not have every thing to do yourself! Why can not you be contented, after having done your share of Labor, to sit, and look on, and see most anybody else do it, even if they could not do it quite as well as you could? At any rate I wish you would occupy yourself a little more in writing to your children!
Do write frequently.
Aff. Son I.S. Metcalf
Completed

I.S. Metcalf
April 15, '47

                                                                                                                                      Orono, April 25, 1847

Dear Mother, 
I received your last letter a few days since, and was as usual much gratified thereby. Nothing hardly seems to do one quite so much good as the reception of letters, especially from home; or, indeed those filled with good news, from dear friends any where. I do not believe that one hundred dollars of money, much as I need it, would have made me feel so well, for the present at least, as the letters or rather the news I received in the letters from College last week. You will say, 'Why, what was it?' and then if you were told, perhaps, why, what is that to you? So I do not know as it is much use to tell you. It was simply the alignment of parts, that is of the College honors, in the next clap. Which came out exactly as I thought right in favor of my Secret society, and especially of my particular friend Case, of Levant.  So the College knows in the next Class, Junior Class, stand thus among the four Secret Societies and etc.
[approximations of Greek letters]  DKE, 4. YV. 3. ADP.2. XY 1. !!! 
I know it ought to be so, but there has been so many influences at work, so much cunning, that we are often tempted to lose our faith in such things in the Old
Completed

proverb, "that honesty is the best policy." However it seems it has turned out true once more. But I am only wearying your patience with  that which is of course of no manner of interest to you. Well, you may probably expect to see me at Milo in a little more than a fortnight. I shall probably close my school at the expiration of two months, or on the Eighth day of May: and go to Milo perhaps about the tenth or eleventh. 

  When I came here, I expected likely to stay two months and a half, but the number of scholars is dropping off considerable, so that it will not be worth a while, I think. At first I hardly knew what was the matter to find scholars learning one after another, I did not know but there was some dissatisfaction. but I find, "it is the way here." I am assured both by my scholars and by others, on all hands that I am most universally and perfectly popular as a teacher. But the way is here, all begin to go to school; but as soon as the warm weather comes on, and the river opens, the young men begin to leave, some to work in the Mills & about the water etc. etc., and some because the want to play out doors, and their parents cannot keep them in etc. etc.
Completed

So they say that I have done unusually well in the school up in numbers so well and so long, and yet I have lost just about one half of the young men who began to attend. 

 One thing is flattering however, that not a single one of the young ladies has left except one who is sick.      So I have only about 35 or 36 scholars for the last part of the time. I ought to have been informed of the matter beforehand, but if I had I probably should not have come, I was somewhat inclined to be a bit provoked at the man who wrote to me, and who knew all about it. that he did not state the case fairly, and when I found the scholars learning so to quit after the six weeks. But the school that is left seemed to be getting so finely, to feel so bad about the school closing any time soon, that I though I would stay, if I did not get quite so large wages as I expected. 
   You wish Eliab would be more serious. Why? He is, I presume, perfectly steady! and if he enjoys himself highly, in his way, so much the better, is it not? He is certainly a merry fine young man, successful, much liked by his employees; liked by all who know him and that is not a few, as a young man of good abilities & and high promise. What more do you want?
Completed

Joseph is not on to be as generally universally known and appreciated as Eliab perhaps. But those who do know him will perhaps appreciate him still higher, as not only one smart, capable and to by confided in, but also as accurate and profound in what ever he takes hold off. I find that those who know Joseph, perhaps the number is not very large, rate him very high. 
Eliab is known and esteemed by all. 
How shall I get up to Milo? Does Charles ever come to Banger about that time? 
I rather want to go up to Milo, by way of Argyle, Lagrange & through Orneville perhaps. think some after my school closes of walking up round that way, to see the country, And I can send my truck to Banger. 
Excuse this hasty scribbling of a letter. I hope you will write again soon. If Charles is coming down any time then, I should like to hear of it, so I could at least send my trunk by him. little difference though. 
Affectionately I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Bowd, Coll., June 16th, 1847

Dear Mother,
I suppose you would like to hear pretty soon of my arrival at Old Bowd, etc. 
I found at Banger that the fares down the Kennebec were considerable higher than last year, so that route would cost considerable more than that by Portland; Moreover, Case, Rich, and others, wished to go by Stboat. So I spent all day Thursday in Banger, loafing about Friday morning took the Governor for Portland, it was rainy and quite rough, I had not slept very much the night before, so stowed myself away and slept most all the afternoon, thus avoiding seasickness. The next day, yesterday, Case & I walked out here from Portland, We got pretty well tired of it too, I assure you, before you arrived here. However, we "took it easy", and perhaps we may feel all the better for it by & by.

I find things here in about the usual shape. No more of my matters "appropriated" than I expected. Some of my classmates, I had heard were sick, threatened with consumption, S.J. Pike of Brunswick. It is hoped is better it is thought he may possibly recover. My friend Henry J Ware of Athen is is reported is in the last stages, given over by physicians one of my classmates also. John Rogers of Bath has gone off to Europe to spend the summer, so he will not graduate until next year. It is an unfortunate class.
Completed

One thing Joseph told me about, and wanted I should write to you and Charles about, now before I forget it. I never thought of it until Joseph told me, and gave me the proof. Those buildings there, house & barn are insured, and you are paying premiums, assessments or whatever, I do not know how much or how often, upon & for the insurance. The insurance policy in for Buildings of Chas. W. Rich. At the same time Deeds regularly recorded & registered show that said property belongs to some one else. Of course, the Insurance is good for exactly nothing at all. Numerous instances show it conclusively. How foolish it is to be there paying money for what is worse than nothing. Moreover that property ought to be insured, You would all of you be badly off if those buildings were consumed and you had nothing to rebuild with. To say nothing of you creditors, for whose interested you ought to think somewhat. 

Moreover. it will of course do no good to make a transfer of property with the same policy. There must be a new policy of insurance, ought to be in name of A.M. Metcalf, then to be transferred to C.W. Rich whenever the property affairs are settled, which they surely ought to be. 
As for how those things should be settled, I am sure I do not know, Charles thinks one third part of the farm is not worth more than about $500,00 I do not know as it is a real estate in valued there now. I ought to be though. Real estate must be surprisingly low in Milo. Any where in Foxcroft or Dover the same property would be worth at least three times as much, and is there fast rising too. It must rise a good deal in Milo before many years I should think.
Completed

If the Real Estate is estimated at $500,00, the whole personal property would amount to something over $200,00 or $300 more I should suppose. If that ought to be reckoned to the House hold furniture etc. as well as the Cattle etc. and I see now why it should not, that is unless Mother wishes to keep all the furniture etc, in her own hands and methinks she needs it not so much as the newly married couple, unless they are intending to fill up their house anew and in style, which would coast towards $1000.00, I believe it is estimated that the cost of furnishing a house properly & suitably should be rather more than the cost of the house. 

 Supposing underlined the Amount underlined or estimated value of Mother's property settled there are difficulties in the way of almost any way I can think of of settling  up the affair. 
Charles, I suppose wishes the farm etc. in his possession He neither wishes to sell or to divide. He does not feel able at present to buy right out. To simply pay the interest every year, would not answer; it would of course leave the ownership of the property not in his hands, which I suppose he wants. The only feasible way I think of is an annuity in some shape. I could be made a life annuity. on the life assurance principles, but with some fuss: and moreover that would be hardly fair as it respects Mother's unmarried daughters who are unprovided for. How would an annuity for 20 year answer? $700, for twenty years would be towards $70, per year I believe,
Completed

[right-hand side]Isaac June 6th / 47
I should think it ought not to be less than that. it is certainly reckoning the property at a very low rate, whether we consider what it has cost, or its present aspect.
It is rather a hard business on both sides to be sure.
I hardly see what I am to do for money.
I expect I must have about $100,00 dollars before the 1st of Sept. in order to pay up all my bills here, and Graduate with my Class. I hoped last winter it could be a little less than that, upon present appearances it is rather likely to be more.

I have certainly been very economical, people hardly believe me, when I say that I in my college course have earned money to meet all my Expenses. within $100,00

But Where is the $100,00 to come from?
I suppose Lucy will be at home this week, probably when this reaches there. I do not mean to write to her much just this time on this paper, but rather conclude she better write to me. It seems a great while since she has written. If any of those letters arrived at Milo since I left there were for me, I think they had better be sent on this way immediately, with additions etc. perhaps.
I want to know whether Lucy took cold that Afternoon I feared she would.  Also all about the _________ PicNic, or whatever name it goes by. Luct now give me the Whole story, do. Do not be afraid of using up more than one sheet of paper! All of you must write to me Often.
Completed

Bowd. Coll. July 18th, 1847
Dear Mother,
You can hardly imagine how much I was gratified at receiving yesterday a letter from Milo, I had almost begun to doubt the existence of any such place, or at least of any people dwelling there. I had been in Brunswick six full weeks, and had heard never a word from there, although I had written two or three times I believe. However, perhaps I was glad enough at receiving the letter at last to make up for some of the waiting.  However if it is to be so long before I receive answers to letters, I think I do well to write pretty soon after receiving one.
As for my health, about which you always appear to feel so much anxiety, I have the pleasure of informing you that I never enjoyed better in my life. I am perfectly well, stout, rugged, and healthy, eat like an ox, and sleep accordingly; can tire out my fellows at most any thing, and not worry me; swim three hours per diem, (if I choose), and feel all the better for it.  On the whole, I study some, read more, and get along very comfortably, except when some unlucky circumstance slightly reminds me of pecuniary affairs; but even that, for one as good natured & careless as I am, never lasts a great while.  Did I understand you that you hoped I would have one severe fit of sickness just to teach me to take care of my health?!  I am careful.
Completed

As for what I am to do, or how I am to do it, I am sure I know not. I suppose, if I can get along no other way, I might borrow money enough to get away from Brunswick, leaving my bills all unpaid, of one of the boys; though it might perhaps be some inconvenience to them.  What I am to go to doing I am sure I do not know, & cannot tell or guess. I had about made up my mind, that, now, as I had got my education and begun to be in a situation to be a little independent, that is, in degree, that I would teach school no more. I really do not like it very well, am not at all inclined to adopt teaching as a profession, or permanent business, and do not think it well to spend time, more than one can help, in any such by play. Teaching is certainly not of very much benefit as a preparation for any other occupation or mode of life,  Still I may be obliged to teach a little more; if I should go West immediately I should probably have to teach at first.  But I do not want to.  I should like to go upon a RailRoad, to study engineering, think I should be pretty well fitted for that, and stand some chance of succeeding.  But I do not know as there is much chance of my being able to make a beginning, to get into a situation.  I am not
Completed

But it is not very likely perhaps that I can get such a situation right away; There are many who want just such situations. And as long as it is the influence of rich men, R.R. Directors &c. which procures situations for relatives & favorites, rather than real fitness, education, or abilities; I am perhaps not very likely to succeed; at the said Rich men's influence happens to be the very article in which I am poorest; more so even than in money, for that I can earn. The other there are two ways in which people possess it. Most who have it, have it by right of birth: that I certainly have not. Some can obtain it by that sort of "faculty for good graces" which some possess, or by "bending the pliant hinges of the knee, where thrift may follow fawning!" With the first I take it nature has not gifted me; if indeed it be any thing different from the latter, for which I am far too independent to try. 
This day is Sabbath, July 10th, One week from Tuesday, or the 24th I shall get through with Bowdoin College.  If I should go home should probably go in the course of that week, in about one week after this letter will reach you. If I can find any thing to do I shall not go home; if I cannot, perhaps I shall, though if I had a little money I thing  I should go to Mass. first.
I have been pulling all the strings I knew how to get hold of, only three or four, to try to get upon a R. Road, immediately.  I had a letter from Uncle Joseph Stevens a short time since I wrote to him about the R.R. business there. He wrote as soon as he got my letter, very kindly, approved my ideas, if he could do any thing for me he would try.  The engineers had left his vicinity, but he was acquainted with some, on other roads &c. He would see some of them &c.
Completed

He wrote that he had lately received a letter from you, from which he learned that Charles was married three months before.
Said he supposed "they did not want to write till they found whether he lived"! etc. Wanted me to come there as soon as I am "dismissed" etc. I wrote to an Engineer  on the Portsmouth & Concord Rail Road with whom I was somewhat acquainted, and received a rater discouraging though friendly reply from him.

 Lucy, I have thought it a little strange that you have not written a little more lately.

Joseph's Herbarium (I hope you have not written to him about it, although I intended to have told him) is at Bowd. Coll. and is receiving large and valuable additions. Are you Botanizing much this Summer? I think you had better. Have you a Bigelow? You ought to have. How many letter have I written to you that you have never answered?
If I should come home next week, I should hope you will not begin to arrange plants in your new Herbarium till I arrive. Study & preserve them.
I can get 4 or 5 dollars for my Carpet and guess I had better sell it here. It is so much worn it would not do you great service, if you could cit it up to advantage for one of your rooms. I shall have done things to bring or send home.
I believe I have about written out my paper and the daylight, if not my ideas.

                                                                Aff. I.S. Metcalf.

[right side]Isaac July 18th /47
Completed

Warwick, Sept. 10th 1847
Dear Mother, 
I received a letter from you , or rather from Lucy, the morning I left Brunswick, and I believe,wrote something in answer to it: but, I suppose you would like to hear some account of my doings and peregrinations, and observations since then. Well, suppose I begin a the beginning, and tell you the whole story. 
Friday morning, Sept 3rd, I left Old Bowdoin perhaps for the last time, by stage for Bath $.50 then a ticket for Boston for $1.50,  steamboat Huntress to Portland, the Rail Road to Boston, where we arrived at 9 p.m. and I stopped at the Marlboro Hotel, intending to go Sat by R.R. & Stage to Northfield. But by mistake of my Landlord, or rather of his porters, my valise in the morning went the wrong way, and I could not go until too late. However, the gentlemanly Landlord, Mr. Coe, made many apologies, and told me to stop till Monday, free of expense. So I staid, and Saturday, called round to see the people.
Called at Mrs. Childs, her health improving. She has not been very well, her daughters pretty good for her. A Mrs. Reed there, from Winchendon or Winchester of somewhere, from whom they thought you would be interested to hear, though unfortunately seeing so many people & things since, I cannot remember who & what they said, much
Completed

Her Mother I think they said was at Winchester, or somewhere helping house for her, while absent, & I did not think then I should forget so much. I ought to have written before now. Mrs. Reed appeared a very pretty sort of woman. A young Lady, Hannah Tewksbury, I believe, called to see her, used to live with her, quite pretty, attending school at Newton or somewhere Mrs. Child gave me and old Pocket Book!
Called on Mrs Chase just returned from the Country not Royalston though, all well. 
Mr. B.B. Bush died suddenly a week, fortnight ago, went out to Mr. Auburn, complained of feeling ill, returned died instantly, or almost so. I believe I tell the story right. 
I found Cousin Humphrey etc.
Sabbath A.M. Went into the Marlboro Chapel, large, fine Church. Rev. Matthew Hale Smith, of whom you have heard once Universalist preached his first sermon before the new so called "Pilgrim Church" House crowded full, say 1000 more. Fine preacher. Text "This is none other than the house of God, the gate of Heaven". P.M. I looked in to half a dozen Churches. Winter Street, Mr. Rogers, crowded full, great quire etc. Summer St. Trinity Church. Great Aristocratic Episcopal, Splendid house. Once in a while a Worshipper a child or a woman occasionally in the great pews, to hear their pompous service. Same also in some of the rich great Unitarian Churches, and at Old South. Near by a Second Advent man roaring away wretched nonsense at an awful rate, to a few inferior looking hearers, hear him though half a dozen streets. 
Evening Park St. Missionary Concert etc.
The Aristocratic are not the Church going
Completed

Monday morning rain. Took the cars for Worcester with Humphrey Stevens who was going on to Albany, as his man Alby had by Telegraphic dispatch requested. He had a great journey, though the Western States last year, 15000 miles 11 1/2 months.
From Worcester by Northfield & Brattleboro Stage to Warwick by way of Barre Petersham. Of all the enough country that ever I heard of it beats every thing. The road itself not very lively, but more crooked than ten Earhorns, away round one awful rocky, little hill, then leaping over to just such an then, to mind round to still another in the same way: and soon all day long! Not an acre of land to be seen! but still abundance of farming and orcharding, on little spots of Earth, mashed into hallows among the rocks & ledges. I got out of the stage at a Mr. M. Williams, the nearest point to Warwick village, following a map of "Road to Capt. Joe's" projected upon my note book by H. Stevens Esq. Uncle Joseph not at home, Greenfield. However, they appeared glad to see me. All well. Next day, Tuesday, 7th, I went up to Aunt Conants; staid all day. They are all well. Hervey has quite a pretty little wife and two children, and just going next day have now gone, all four, to Barnard, Vermont, to see Samuel. Aunt C. I think should have known any where, from her resemblance to you. Uncle Conant complains much of growing old, deafness. He could understand every word I said though. I guess I talk very distinctly. He works as regularly as ever he did. I should guess does exactly as much work. What an awfully "Austere Man" he is to look at ! I guess he is rather good though.
Completed

4
And Aunt Conant! I cannot begin to tell how good she is. And all is exactly like my Mother, only older. She is, or might have been, a really superior woman, far too much to see here been confined to such a little narrow contracted sphere. Seemed to me just as if no one thing, even to chip in the dooryard had been moved about there for 16 years! So in the house. So you believe that old wooden Settle has ever been started half an inch from its place? I don't! I did really love Aunt Conant though. And every thing so like my Mother even to cooking and setting the table and washing up the dishes.
Uncle C. I always remember by Deacon - at Bangor who looks so much like him, only younger. Hervey. I think looks just as he used, no older.
Wednesday, I started to go over to Unclear Williams. took me a full hour & more to get from Uncle Joseph's to the village. It is positively the most difficult road I ever traveled. So many and so might are the blackberries, that I could not possibly get along. At the village I met Uncle Joseph returning. Knew him instantly. Rather a good looking  Old Fellow. Looks some like a butcher, if he had given up the trade; east, laughing good natured way. I concluded to go back home with him. He bought from over Northfield, Joseph's wife Jane, with her pretty good matured little Eleven months old boy Wells. I do not see as Uncle Joseph had grown old very much, though he just discovered that he is beginning to go bald.
Completed

5
Uncle Joseph is improving much his little rocky pinched up half bit of a farm. Uses lots of Bog Mud & Ashes, clearing of swamp, holes & everything. Makes it profitable to Power? full of hay. I should think more than in Uncle Conant's tho. Hires a Man and a boy. Uncle Joseph appears to be a very popular man; and is really a very capable business man, for one of his "Eddication." very well informed. I judge the whole set take them together, here and at Northfield, a very happy family. Wednesday was a rainy day, and Thursday Morn. Wed. P.M. Came a Mr. Lewis (and wife and daughter) whose son Lenas is Uncle Joseph's hired man from Winchester. Mrs. Lewis, who used to be "Bing" or "Viny" or "Livy" Conant, much pleased to know who I was, inquired much after all the folks, sent much love. As by the way do every body many else. All which I do herely deliver. Appears quite a woman just about Charles' age, rather got the start of him thought, I judge by her stout Whiskered son, and the daughter her Her Mother (or somebody else) living near here, is sick and like to die; Consumption, I guess. I enquired of her for Josiah K. Metcalf of Royalston said to be teaching School at Winchester. Was so good, and much liked; but then just gone home to attend the funeral of his mother, or rather Step Mother. Next day. Thurs rainy morning, clearer P.M. Funeral of a young man - Abbott, 23 years old. Student, I believe just died of Consumption. Several deaths likely, among Mr. Hodges, of whose Children Unclear is guardian.
Completed

Thursday P.M. I walked over to Royalston, got there just before or as it began to rain hard. Folks at Uncle Jacob's well, except much worn down by fatigue and grief. Mrs. Metcalf, formerly Mrs Thomas of Winchester, taken sick Wednesday night, Inflammation of the Bowels, or something of the kind, extreme suffering but I believe not thought dangerously until Sabbath night or Monday morning. Died Monday eve. Buried Tuesday P.M. Josiah came home Monday, went back to his School Wednesday. The blow seemed to fall most heavily upon Mrs. Metcalf's daughter, Ms. Nancy S. Thomas by it left as it were entirely alone in the world. Her own father, as well as only Brother and Sister having previously died and not Mother too! When I became acquainted with her, I liked her much. She seemed "cast down, but not destroyed". Very much supported. I judged that she is to be married to Mr. Jos. Walker a well appearing young man, who was there, and with whom I believe Eliab is acquainted, perhaps a correspondence. At any rate I was much pleased with her appearance. 
Uncle Jacob looks old is and shows to be, to have been, and to be still a very hard working man But what a good kind man he is; perfectly ready, and most happy, to do any thing and every thing any personal sacrifice or effort whatever, to oblige, please or benefit, any one. Why there is not one young man or boy in ten thousand hardly, who would jump over a fence now so quick as he would at his age, to gratify any one. How I do love him! I know he is a great deal like my father, in many things.
Completed

Josiah went back to his school Wednesday. Samuel, widower, hires or boards there with his father. Harriet Prescott's Widow, Mrs. Brewster that now is, who lives an Worcester, was up there. I like her very much. Her Oldest, Harlan Peletiah lives, has always lived, with his Grandfather, a real good little fellow too. 9 years. Prescott Mrs. Brewster bought up with her. In the afternoon, it did not raid. I went with Samuel up to the other place, and up where Father used to live. Every thing seemed to look just as I could remember it, only smaller, narrower, and as if crowded up together, the houses seemed so near, instead of away off as I thought them. I went into the house, the Old Kitchen seemed so little. I suppose I remember it as it seems to me when I used to creep across its floor, and think it a long ways. Mr. Newton, who lives there has had a stroke of palsy, and cannot speak so as to be understood or hardly more about. The farm I guess is not very well cultivated, or any thing in good repair. They say it is exactly as father left it. No Improvement of course going backward. The farther part of the shed building is all rotted down, looks as if five pounds weight would crumble it. Samuel & I called at Mr. Russell Morse's, Sen. & Jun. My old playmate has two or three stout babies! The Old Man, Samuel said is Rich. We went back across. What a tremendous hill that is. After supper, Samuel carried me over to Mr. Obediah Stoddards, whose wife Esther, it appears is my Cousin, though I knew nothing of her, or she of me. She has got a pretty little girl though. Her husband it seems is quite a wealthy farmer.
Completed

8
Col. Brown is very sick not expected to live. O. Goddard has gone off to try and find his son, Wm, I believe who had gone peddling.
Went to the burying ground
Every body I saw any where knew Capt Issac and was ever so glad to see his son. One rusty Old fellow, Calvin Forbes by name passed me in Uncle's orchard had and exalted remembrance of you, my Mother, for, let me tell you, making him the best mug of punch that ever he drank, when he was once threshing Oats there. How much good that did him! There had not been a week since when he had not thought of it and of you! etc. etc. Chas Rich was the very worst boy that ever he knew any thing about supposed Capt Metcalf would have trained him if any body could but he could do nothing with him. Sent to bring Forbes dinner he would stop to play & sometimes got there before sundown!
Sat morning, I walked back to Warwick expecting to see Cousin Joseph but he not yet return from Boston, and no come Saturday. P.M. in rain went over with Uncle Jos to Mr. Williams, all well. S.E. Baldwin Waldron, Yale student, Lucy W's man there. Lucy appears to be a very fine smart girl, got a grand new piano. Aunt Esther there, does not look six months older or different at all from a dozen years ago. She is going to Barnard Ver. to spend the winter. Baldwin & Lucy have just returned from Monadnock. There, if you are not satisfied with news and ?. I will give it up. Aff. I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Northfield Sept 23d 1847
Dear Mother I believe I wrote to you a very long, though perhaps very careless letter, about a week ago, from Warwick. I write again, not really because I have much to communicate but rather because I am so extremely  desirous anxious to hear something from "Down East" from home; and I do not see much probability of it, if I do not write. It is now more than four weeks since I left Milo and about three since I have heard a single word in any way from Milo or Bangor. When I wrote before I said nothing I believe of whither you could write to me. And I don't know as I am now in fact much more settled than then. However, you can direct letters to me her at Northfield, and I am any where in this region, I shall be pretty likely to receive them sometime. I do not now perceive much probability that I shall get away from hereabouts immediately, whether I get a situation on the Rail Road eventually, or not. This is, I do not see as it is likely to be decided right away. So I hope you will write letters to me immediately.
Completed

I think I wrote in my last letter a very prolix account of all my doings, goings, and seeings, until the 11th inst. The 11th after returning from Royalston, I went over to Uncle Williams'. The 12th, Sabbath, I herd A.M. Rev. Mr. Clark the new Unitarian Clergyman and P.M. " " Kenney Baptist Clergyman of West Royalston exchanged with Mr. Hatch! 12th Monday I came over to Northfield with Cousin Joseph A.S. and have been here much of the time since. Writing - loafing getting acquainted & sometimes working in the Bark Mill, or doing any thing else I could find. They say that I am sure of employment on this road sometime - The Chief Engineer Edwards, has told me there is no doubt of it. But there great things more slow you know. They have just concluded to go on with a great deal of business this Fall -- when they get ready - And Engineers are Scarce. This Vermont R.R. is to be pressed in not only to Brattleboro, but far beyond, up river, Bellows Fall & I don't know where else. And above all that The Directors of this Road, and of Fitchburg, and others have decided to make immediately a great survey for a route from this Road say from Brattleboro, across the Mountains to Troy N.Y.  4 or 5 thousands $ have been already appropriated for the preparatory survey, exploration
Completed

Just how they are all waiting for some formal action of Directors of something or other. I do not know who understands their machinery. But when they do start, maybe tomorrow next week or next month, I expect I am pretty sure of Employment. Last Sabbath A.M. I heard Rev. Mr. Kendall of Bernardston, exchanged with Mr. Jones, Orthodox Clergyman here. P.M. Rev Mr. Locke of New Salem, exchanged with Mr. Everett Unitarian. Monday 20th P.M. I walked over to Winchester, and went into Select School of Cousin Josiah K. Metcalf astonished him considerable when I introduced myself after School was over. I guess he is a pretty good school Master, but not likely to be much of any thing more that that. Stopped there with him Monday night, and returned here, Tuesday A.M. P.M. walked over by and old road through the woods to Uncle Williams' in Warwick. Mr. Baldwin still there. Makes it his home there I should judge. Wednesday a beautiful clear morning went over on Mount Grace with Baldwin. Had a splendid time, the most mountain climbing, I ever met with, and by great odds the noblest prospects I ever say. Baldwin had a very good spyglass. Could see with naked eye Mts Washington, Monadnock, Wachusett, Holyyoke etc. etc. with the glass, Villages to the South & East - many Royalston, Athol, Templeton, Petersham, New Salem, Orange, Statesbury, etc. etc. Winchester looks most beautifully, and the valley leading thither & every thing else in fact. Returned here P.M.
Completed

Feb. 23d 1848 Northfield
Dear Mother
After long waiting, and some impatience, I received you letter Monday Eve. 21st inst. I t had got to be about six weeks since I wrote before. It will not do for me to delay writing long after receiving letters from Milo, if I wish to get replies the same season! However, considering the circumstances, and the important events, which have lately transpired, there is some apology for the delay in this last case. I think though that I ought to have been apprised of the great fact a week sooner. Seemed to me I want to see the young gentleman. What will they call his name? Charles? Of course. Couldn't find a better, except it were ! Isaac!!! How does Charles ensure his dignity? How I should like to be there to admire his paternity. Why couldn't you tell me how the little fellow looks? Or has in that matter been decided yet?! It is a little curious that Charles should be away in the woods. Rather a great idea to find himself a father so unexpectedly. I do not see how he can go back into the woods again and leave his baby! It is a pity I had not his oxen here if that is all that sends him off. $28.00m per month thought I should think was doing pretty well, all expenses paid; that is, if he gets his pay. Pay "Cash down"? Am much obliged for you account of "relation" I shall rely upon you however to come and introduce me to some of them in the Spring. By the way, Jos. A. Stevens who was at Boston Saturday told me that the oldest son
Completed

Isaac Feb. 23rd / 48
of Uncle 'Nathan' Stevens , I think it was of Petersham or Barre died the other day: fine boy 12 or 14 of age. Joseph's little boy, I do love a good deal. The poor little fellow is quite sick. was unwell a month or so, got better nicely a week or two, yesterday taken quite sick, they could not bare him to come out to Temperance Celebration. You ask if I have become acquainted with the Barbers. Least week I called on a Mr. Dutton, a very fine man. I  think who said some of his cousins were my cousins, his mother was sister of Mr. Williams of Warwick. His wife is a fine woman. At his house I was introduced to a Miss Barber, quite a pretty lisping young lady. A Mr. Barber I have heard of as a meanest man, is Member of the Church. Rev. Mr. Jones is stating to me the resources of his parish, said that Mr. Barber last 1846 year paid $2.00 for support of preaching. This year 1847 he was so poor he could pay nothing!

You seem to write as if it might be uncertain whether you would come back with me in the Spring! It is just exactly as uncertain as it is whether we both live till that time. At any rate I shall not come back without you. And if I should not be able to go Down East in the Spring. Why then you must come. 
As for money, I will have enough for that matter by that time, so do not invent any more excuses. Besides, they ought to be ready to given me free passes over some Railroads by that time.
 The fact is, at any rate there is no sort of necessity on propriety in you keeping yourself shut up there at Milo, at the rate you have done for so long.
Completed

Sabbath Evening, March 5th, 1848, Northfield
Dear Mother. I believe I much begin to write again to you and Lucy for it I want after writing once even till I receive your letter; the time becomes so long that I almost forget even writing before "The Stormy March had come at last!" After a winter of almost unexampled mildness, very little snow, no sleighing for a week together any time I believe, hardly any cold weather except a week or two we were out up to Brattleboro; March bids fair to be; at any rate had thus for shown itself, boisterous enough.

 Today had been real March weather: changing half a dozen times from bright melting sunshine, to dark gusty snow storms, and a wind that cuts like a knife, raising the snow in clouds, even as it melts under the high Spring Sun.
    At the Monthly concert - this afternoon, Dea. Field from another town being present, gave an interesting account of a Revival, lately & now, going on in the town of Heath, west part of this county. 
A real Revival, like those of other days, which have been so scarce almost unknown for there or four years past. How it does warm ones' thoughts, so that, according to the Psalmist, the fire burns within, to hear again such doing of the Lord. I bought back to my mind the former days, at Brownville in 1842.
 Oh that the Lord would again vouchsafe to visit his people in Mercy to extend gracious influences of his spirit on every side. How careful too ought Christians to be lest they again excite the displeasure of God as in time past.
 The Churches about here, I think must be in extremely bad state; far worse than I know any thing about Down East. Many of them as I hear full of old breaches, divisions, wounds, & some that will not be healed up: often hearing called council after council, and every one leaning matters worse then before. This Church has been in the same way, and that long: difficulties now sleep perhaps only because there is not life enough to show it. As the man who is struck down by apoplexy does not complain of a foul stomach. As I understand from Mr. Jones, there has never been really a revival of Religion in this town! One of the oldest towns too. Mr. Field said that in Heath there have been 10 councils besides References in 10 years.
Completed

Isaac Mar. 6, 1848
There are great times just now among the Irish laborers along the Rail Roads about here. Wages have been this winder &.70 per day for shovellers. That is little enough to be sure considering that they may not be able to work more then 15 or 20 days in a month and their board costs them generally about $2.25 or more per week. But since March came in, and the wages not raised, they have had a general "Strike for higher wages!" all along on this Road and others simultaneously. Not content with stopping work themselves, you see, they undertake to all from working whether they wish or not; marching along the line sometimes three of four hundred together armed with clubs & pick handles, stopping the crews who did not strike, in some instances, destroying cards, shovels, etc. Most of the works about here stopped when the rest did, but as yet there have been no overt acts. Some think the mobs will show themselves here within a few days, to break up the crews who are still at work on the bridges etc. No one knows what will be. One of the bridge contractors, who has a crew still at work down on Miller's River, had armed himself with two or three "Revolvers" declaring that no one shall drive his men off the works. He is a resolute fellow too.

I think now I shall continue some way to get off here a week or two the last of April or in May. I rather think they will let me go, if they are not extremely and unusually hurried. I have certainly been very steady at business since I have been here and indeed am in such a situation that they owe it to me. Moreover, those with whom I have to do are the best  sort of men to get along with. Mr. Field my immediate director is a great friend of me, and ready to do any thing to oblige me; and Mr. Johnson, the Chief Engineer, has the reputation of being very obliging in such matters. To be sure, leave of absence for an Engineer is something not usual or to be expected. The universal answer to applications is No. If a Junior ever gets leave of absence it is a special favor. It is a kind or work that cannot stop and no one can take another place for a few days or a week. However, you may fairly expect Me; so of course Mother be ready to come back with me at once. At any rate to come.
Completed

[Upside down at top] I believe 100.00 expense in orcharding, ten, perhaps even five years ago might have made Charles' property  1000.00 better now.
Dear Mother & Dear Sister Lucy, I have again got about tired waiting for a letter from you, and do not see but I must begin again to write in advance!  I believe it is pretty near a month since I wrote last. Does it begin to look any like Farming Down East yet? Folks hear abouts have begun to plough a little. and prepare Gardens, in dry situations. The frost is pretty well out of the Ground, the Road considerably settled, the grass is springing, the buds swelling. The rye fields, (rye appears to be a principal crop here) look beautifully Green.
Frogs, snakes, and birds are abundant this fortnight. Blue birds are extremely abundant & little shy; Robins more scarce than in Maine. I think. Since the first of April I have been out of doors all the time, indeed of about half, and enjoy it much. There is prospect of rather a busy time next month; but then I am getting work done up pretty good jog, that is may be in a state of forwardness, so I can get away. Did you ever know any thing about this town of Northfield; Mother, when you lived in Milo? I believe it would be difficult to find any where, a more idle, shiftless, good for nothing, vicious, set of people than are to be found in this street. Mr. Fields, and he, like most perhaps who call themselves Unitarians, is really little better than an Infidel; Mr. Field ascribes the present character of the inhabitants to the "preaching" under which they were brought up. I think lately that might be the case. Did you ever know of, or hear of , "Old Priest Mason."  He was dismissed from the Church here several years since, still lives here, but has never entered the Church from that day till this. I believe he is about as thorough an old Pirate as ever lived. Certain it is that his influence, and he has some, for he is a man of considerable ability, is entirely in opposition to a every good thing. He is an infidel, at any rate, I am informed by those who
Completed

I.S.M. April = 48
ought to know, that he was never known to believe anything: his creed is entirely negative. He is an intemperance man. uses it himself, owns, leases, and supports a miserable Irish Grog Shop. Mr. Birnie, the Bridge Contractor has tried every way to hire or buy the whole premises, for the trouble it makes to him and his men; but the old reprobate wont. Quite a proportion of the people I judge to be fit followers for such a head.  I have found but two or three younger men of Northfield, that I would call decently respected anywhere else.

  I do not know but I ought to tell you the story of my fit of sickness and my getting drunk lately.  It may make you talk to me about being careful of my health.  Though in fact, I am never careless; in proof of which, I can say I have not taken a cold at all for the winter or spring.  I usually have a cold sometime latter part of the winter; but this year have entirely escaped; and my health has been perfect: ~ but ~ about a week since I had a sort of Nervous fever which lasted two or three days, in which time I did not sleep, and hardly rested still in one place one whole minute at a time. There was a terrible burning much of the time in my face, alternated by a dull pain among my teeth & cheek bones. Perhaps, you know I am a Hydropathist. Well, I could cure the symptoms quite easily by the regular water cure, laying cloths from cold water over my face etc. but I could not thus remove the cause, the nerves, and the fever would return. At last I got out of patience, went to the doctor, took a good dose of Chloroform, got pretty drunk, calmed my nerves down, went to sleep, and waked up perfectly well.  On the whole it was quite a fit of sickness for me. was not it?
 Isn't this an early Spring? or is it earlier here than in Maine? I picked a nice bunch of May Flowers today 13th  Farmers busy ploughing etc .

Any sort of a decent horse is worth $100.00 here. 6 1/2 fat cattle 90. to 100. Tell Charles whether he does any thing else or not this year to do something about Orcharding. I believe good orchards may be on the Intervale profitably. All wanted is care.
Completed

July 11th PM. 

Dear Mother, 
I am very busy. I will send our Lucy's last letter, to you. You see how she want to hear from you; have you not written at all to her yet. I wrote again in answer to this letter sent yesterday 10th sent one to Joseph July 4th. I do hope you will come out here. wish you would. Albert's folks, you know have moved over into his father's house and Jane is all alone nowadays. No men even now. 

 It has been very sickly here lately: most every body is getting well now though I believe. Will at any rate if this pleasant weather continues. 
  If Joseph goes out to Warwick you must come back with him if not if I could get liesure try to come out for you.
Completed

Northfield July 21st, 1848. 

Dear Mother
I do not know as I shall make this letter to reach you; but I thought I would try. I suppose you are at Winchester this week, as least so they tell me down at Cousins. 

I wished you had come here this week instead, and guess you had better next week at least. My object in writing this to know what say will come down here, if I will come up to Winchester for you, If you can write tomorrow Friday to send by the Afternoon stage: I will come up Saturday; that is I think now I can. Should like to today or tomorrow. 
I think you ought to stay a spell with Joseph and Jane. You can hardly how desolate desolate they are I think they might be peculiarly susceptible of good influences now. You know James' Mother is a pious good woman. Jane told me yesterday, "how much she should prise your society just now." Do come 
 I should like too to have you be here and so a little work for me sometimes, if you have time & convenience. 
       When do you think of going to Royalston?
Completed

I.S. Metcalf july 21st = 48 
They say it is quite sickly here there are many sick about here, principally children. 

 I do not know of any deaths though except those at Parson's & Stevens.' 

I have no letters from Maine lately.
Affec. I.S.
I hope, if you get this you will write by the return mail tomorrow.
Completed

Northfield Sept 2d. 1848
Dear Mother,
I was hoping somewhat to hear from some of you by last night's mail, but perhaps you did not get down East in Season, and perhaps if you did you would all be too glad to get home to think of writing to me. So perhaps I better not expect  a letter for a month or so. It is rather curious how defective some of your children are in the art of speech. Some people now can always say just what they wish to, at just the right time. Perhaps it is partly some defect in the brain which does not think of thinks at the right time to say them. Since you went away I keep thinking of things that I really wanted to say, and talk about, to you, & to Lucy, and the rest of you. I began to believe it will not do for me to depend much upon the faculty of speech, as a medium for thoughts; if ever do think of anything I must put it on paper.  
One think I intended to mention to you, that I wish you would speak to Charles about when you get to Milo. You know it has been always allowed that Charles on the place there somehow owed me something. Charles himself said three of four years go that he was going to pay me $100.00 and it was certainly justly my due. I have done more than that worth of hard work these some of it too hard, since I was twenty or twenty one years old. Besides the money that I earned away from home before I went to College more then I ever had any benefit from myself. The fact is I ought to have had those earnings. There was property an
Completed

means enough these for the rest of you: and I needed it for more than any of the rest of the family: One hundred dollars was worth just about a hundred dollars to Charles & the rest of you, sometimes perhaps a little more, possibly $150.00. To me at that time it was work truly worth more than $1000. In fact no money, just the mere property can estimate the benefit of one or two hundred dollars to me just the right time. This Cutting down, "razeeing", a ship builder might call it, a man from "second rate" to "third rate", is not very easily estimated. Yet it is a think very easily done by a little too much of difficulties, or too little of advantages at a critical time. To be sure the man may yet be a very useful man. In some cases indeed he may get clear up again. With a really "first rate", this may be easy enough. When a man had really distinguished himself as a genius, he become a great statesmen, orator, author: they do not stop to enquire whether he got an Oration at College, or indeed whether he has ever seen a college. But with us Common men the case is very different. If the student was not quite high enough for a "Phi Beta-Kappa", nothing he can ever do afterwards will give him an Election and if he does not get higher than a "Common Man's" ambition ought to lead him, then will be apt to remember what he was not, rather what he is. But all this is wandering from the subject; is nothing at all to the purpose. I was going to say that perhaps the matter ought to be decided some how. The fact that I did not have it when I needed it much and ought to have had it, may not prove that I ought not to have it sometimes. I may still need it more than any one else. In a primary point of view I certainly am the poorest of the family, and perhaps am likely to remain so; that is in
Completed

comparison with my actual necessities, my needs of money. Now would it not be a good plan for you to mention that matter to Charles find what he feels about it; whether he thinks he owes me any thing, and intends to pay it; and if he does, just get him to send me his note for the sum with interest from some date, back, forward, or present. There appears to be a rather long story, fast; Excuse it, for I may not think of it again, any more than I did when you were here or when I have been at Milo.
What shall I do if I am thrown out of business here, this Fall or Winter and cannot find any other situation? That is the greatest trouble in Engineering; it is not a permanent business and  the getting a situation is perhaps the worst thing about it. Perhaps I was unfortunate in beginning on a road partly finished. The Vt. & Mass. R.R. is now near completion some say it will be finished by Dec 1st at any rate: some say Jan1st, some indeed, next spring. But then that cannot heed so much help at the end you know have been lately turning off some, more will be without doubt before the road is complete. To be sure, they tell me I shall probably be wanted as long as any one; and perhaps I may; as I believe I have made myself pretty useful for my standing & salary: Still I cannot expect always to be favored, even at the expense of those who have friends to book out for them. The Question is, what had I better do? My object of course is to get ahead as fast as possible. Can I do better than to go South, if I can get an opportunity? There I could expect better wages and more rapid advancement; and perhaps full as good opportunity to
Completed

make valuable friends. Perhaps I might like best, even at less wages & poorer prospects, a situation on one of of the Maine Rail Roads; say perhaps Bangor to Waterville: But then I have no influence to push me into a situation to rich or stationed relative, or particular friend, whose influence would help me, or to please whom somebody would take the pains t help me. Most folks now that amount to any thing, except some very few that used to be called geniuses, though the existence of any such animal has somewhat fallen in doubt if these latter times have somebody to help them. Comparatively few really help themselves, as our folds are obliged to, if indeed, they get any help at all. Our family is unfortunately not "connected" if you know what that means.

 It might be curious to trace away round, just how much ever such a man as say Mr. Field here owes to being connected, (and that through rather disreputable channels even of families of drunken paupers) with certain Congress man or Custom House Officers or somebody whose influence would affect something somewhere. This matter of influence is one of the prerequisites of wealth, situation; sometime perhaps talent and being generally less valued than money, is often turned over to "poor relations" & to whom it may be more valuable if possible than to that rich itself. 
There - I have written pretty near four pages of something. Come to read it over, I hardly think I had better try to add any thing to it. It is getting to be rather late to think of writing a letter on this sheet.
Completed

top of letter*
apply to the Mothers. I do not write specially to Almeda. It is no use. if I write the whole and you all read it, no matter to whom I direct it. Almeda why can you not write to me & Albina too. I want to hear about the Children, & of course must
Northfield Farms, Oct. 3d, 1848
Isaac
Dear Mother,
I am away from home, and have not the best materials or apparatus at hand for letter writing; but what is somewhat rarer, I have a bit of leisure; so, if you will excuse it, I will try to 'perpetrate' a letter, though I hardly know as you can read it, with this paper & ink.
I received your letter I guess about a week since. It seems Anne is really going, or rather has already gone. I hardly knew any thing about it until I got your letter, although I believe Joseph has just mentioned in his letter, in his dry matter of fact way, the possibility of such a thing. Since I received yours however, I have another letter from Joseph two days since: he states that she has already left Bangor, that Charles & Almeda were down to see here. I confess, I seemed to know nothing about it; and her leaving Bangor seemed rather strange to me. Joseph says he finally thinks "it is for the best: he knows better than I, and I can rely upon his judgement.
You suppose I know all about the Society etc.
All of you have better opportunity to know such things, for a year past, than I. I know only that it is a Benevolent to be depended upon certain, and so is Miss Beecher.
You wanted me to advise Anne etc. I could'nt very well do that. I "took time" however, since receiving Joseph's letter, and wrote to Anne at Hartford, and also to "The Directors of the Ladies Society for the Promotion of Education at the West". Whether the letters will reach their destinations I know not, and do not know as it is very important. 
[left side of letter]
I.S.M.  Northfield F.

Oct. 3. 1848

J. S. M. Northfield F.
Completed

The thing, I judge you feel Ann's going away from Bangor far too much. This being a thousand miles off is a very different thing now from what it used to be
You cannot call it a separation where one can go home in a week any time, or get letters in a day or two, news in an hour perhaps.
Why Anne will not really be one quarter as far off, as you were from your Massachusetts' home, when you first went down East. You old folks are rather behind the times in your appreciation of Modern times and distances {You know People now a days have a way of reversing the old proverb "You folks think old folks are fools, old folks know young folks are so." to be sure I do not pretend to belong to the party: but then without doubt it is more difficult for those who grew up under a different order of things. To accustom themselves to or even to realize the great physical improvements of the age, than for those born & educated among them. To be sure I think you have kept up with the times far better than most folks of your age, and circumstances.
Still Molehills, things now really so, may seen Mountains to you, because they were formerly so called.
Suppose Anne should be settled away at the Far West. Why there is nothing at all in reason, in nature, or in fact, to prevent you yourself from making not one, but many visits to her there.
