And yet how long is it since you pretty much made up your mind that you could not visit even Old Massachusetts again!!!
Charles does seem destined to have his full share of troubles in this World. I do not know though but most other folks do too. It is vexatious to hear of Charles' mishaps, though sometimes; one pull back after another, Still the way is to expect better, hope ever.
Completed

Will he not sell his oxen? The fact is Charles & I are in the same category in regard to the great Yankee faculty of trading readily and profitably. There was that Watch of mine, I might have lived fifty years in the most favorable circumstances an never have sold it.
Eliab took it home with him, and the very first news I got from him was the $18.00 he got for it! Pity Charles could not get him to see his oxen and hay for him. It is really amusing to me to see how Joseph & Eliab can do things. But I have made up my mind that if I ever get my living in the world, it must be in some other way than by buying or selling: though I can buy very readily and well
Seems to me you did not make a very long visit at Hampden, and could not have had a very pleasant journey home form there, either
Now I tell you, I do not think I shall like it very well if you make a visit of a week to me after I am married!
You did not seem to write much about the folks how you found them all etc. I wanted to hear about that little Charley chap there that I just began to like when I was there last spring. You know I do not often like babies much, excepting some ones 
How it rains! it is a very rainy afternoon: and a very rainy spell. I have worked in the rain most every day for a some time, and this forenoon got a little moist; good hydropathic habits; but this P.M. as Track Layers do not work, & I am in advance; and am away from Northfield "R. R. Office", I find it very pleasant to sit in Mrs. Fields' snug little Parlor, and write.
Completed

The Tract Laying is commenced on this last Division of Vermont Rd Mass. To me attaches the dignity of having the charge of this important operation, "Setting Grades" directing where and how high said track shall be laid in advance of the forty or fifty workmen who pack down the sleepers, and spike down the Rails.
This gives me and my ? assistants plenty of business and as the Track Laying commences at the lower end of the Division, for ten miles from the force, I have now to board most of the time away. Have a very pleasant comfortable place, six miles off, only go home Saturday night & when something is wanted of me there.
Oh, I can tell you some news. Cousin Joseph has dissolved partnership with Albert. You know he lost much by the fire: he thought his remaining Capital not enough for the business. I think very fortunate in settling so easily. couldn't if Joseph had claimed as some would. He receives $100.00 per year of his earnings or savings, and deducts exactly his share of the loss by fire. He wants other business, hopes to get it on R. R. Charge of Depot, Baggage Master or something.
-And- is now at work for the Engineering department with me, one of my men, driving Grade pegs etc.
Joseph is a good fellow. and we are politics this Fall. He & Mr. Field & others & I, are revolutionizing old Northfield. Even Old Northfield, a strong old fashioned Democratic Town, we intend shall give a "Free Soil" majority vote hits Fall.
You know I am no speaker or talker, but I can make a good Free Soil Man out of most any really sensible conscientious man in a short time-- even I 
Give him just the right things to read, we have plenty of it, and say just the right things, about the right time.
Here what a letter I have written. Do write to me often. Love to Almeda & Albina & all the little ones. How is Jenny? is she not going to Lucy's.
Affectionately I. S.
Completed

I.S.M. Northfield                                                                                                                Isaac
Oct. 22, 1848 
                                                                                                            Northfield, Mass. Oct. 22d, 1848
                                                                                                                                                                  Isaa

Dear Mother

                               What would you all have thought if you had found this letter, or at least the next one you received from me, dated at "Mobile, Ala." ? Well you need not be frightened; though I certainly came full as near to it, as the boy did to getting his pig!  My CoWorker on the Vt. & Mass. R.R. Mr. J.L. Leonard, who formerly served under Capt. Childe, now Cheif Engineer of the great "Mobile & Ohio RailRoad" is going: - And- he has just four days including Sabbath, from first hearing of it, to get ready and report himself in New York City ready for the Journey!
 I do not go just at this time as it happens - so my letter is not & at present is not likely to be date at Mobile!

But I went down to Springfield yesterday, and had an "interview" with the "Capt. Childe" himself. I judge that the old gentleman was pleased with my appearance condition etc. He possessed himself of my address etc so that he "could call upon me at any time" he said; and perhaps I may be justified in somewhat expecting some time or other, any time from two months to two year hence, a Call to the aforesaid "Mobile & Ohio R.R."  the greatest Rail Road projected in the world, about five hundred miles long!

I thought it was pretty sudden when I heard the story about it at half past 10 at night & started off for Springfield at three, just to see about it; Got to Springfield, some 50 miles before 8 oclock.  But just think of winding up one's business a good month's work, & starting for Mobile in three days!
Perhaps you would say, would have advised me not to go there, even if I had the chance, and would not have lacked reasons therefore.
Completed

But; - such a chance as that is not to be lightly rejected; one need not expect to have the chance to do it, every day, - every life time. Leonard now, if he can fulfil his trusts as well as I could has secured now a permanent situation for half a dozen years at least, a Situation exactly the thing for a young man, & under, as his friends say, the best Engineer in the W.S.
But I have told quite a story about not going to Mobile.

 When I got home last night I found a letter from Anne dated at Buffalo N.Y.  {As this may reach you before a letter from her} and you may not have heard! She is going to "Racine, Racine Co., Wisconsin" Racine is quite a City six or eight thousand population, on Lake Michigan. A school of Young Ladies, already organised, by the wife of a Pres. Minister, in whose family she is to live. She is to received $150.00 per year, clear of all expense.
 She has had a "truly delightful journey" in company of Gor Slade a perfect pattern of a Christian Gentleman. Stopped at the "Delaran House" in Albany. The young man of Syracuse gave them a Breakfast party Stopped in Rochester four days in the "first families". Genesse Falls etc. A day or two in Buffalo. She describes it as a perfect pleasure trip. You know how enthusiastically she enjoys even a hard journey. Likely as not she has already written all this, & much more to you or at any rate, soon will.  By the way, she say she is going to write four letters a month home! Perhaps she will for the first month. But if she continues to do so, it will be a reformation almost worth her, or any of the rest of you going out there for! If she does so well, who will answer them for her. I will do my part.
 Your last letter I gratefully received a few days since. As for my health, you are fare more alarmed & anxious than the matter deserves. My business of Cautiousness is very large.
Completed

I am extremely careful of health, as of everything else, of health especially as the most important. I enjoy excellent health, & intend to preserve it. Am entirely free from those habits that impair the health of so many, or most. Use no intoxicating drinks, tobacco in any of its forms, even tea & coffee. live, play plainly, keep regular hours, bathe all over every day etc. in fact I serve all laws of health & Morality! Am a remarkable prudent young man! in fact the very last person to excite the fears even of an anxious Mother.

  Why cannot Charles just send me a note for some amount he thinks right, and that settle the matter. Of course he has confidence in me that I would not go and sue the note!

And he could take it up whenever he wanted & found convenient.

 You say you believe I seldom give way to despondency etc. Why did you say that I never do. To be sure I see the dark side, when there is one, sometimes write about it, endeavor to provide against it. But as for thinking of it, dwelling upon it, giving way to it, - while God blesses me with health & reason "sana mens in sano corpse", (a sound mind in a sound body) I don't do it.  More than that I think it is absolutely wicked to do it. We all have blessings & priveliges enough : there are glories & beauties enough spread around us in heaven above and Earth beneath to employ our minds without fretting them about the little paltry troubles with which we can easily imagine we are afflicted. 
 -  There   -  I was just going to quote Proverbial Philosophy, but I have not room here for the whole book, and you can read it yourself. Do you read it nowadays? & does Charles?
 You did not write any thing what Charles thinks of Politics as what he said to my letter. I want to know what people are thinking about Down East, this fall.

Seems to me I could make the half of Piscataquis Co. "Free Soil" tween now and 'Lection almost
Completed

If I should get a good chance to go off South or West within two or three months, I should rather want to go home first; but very probably I could not. The duties & responsibilities & the apparent impossibility of my getting away from here will very likely be increased somewhat by Leonard's leaving. It would be impossible for me to get away from here now. And indeed very likely now they will want me here all the winter, perhaps spring.  Still, if I had a good chance and could get away, it would not be best for me to stay I suppose.  I am most afraid they will want me to go and stay down at "Grouts" where Leonard has been stationed. I do not like the place a bit.

 The place is nothing but just a single tavern, a poor concern, crowded with boarders, workmen on the bridges etc. etc.  and bad enough: that would be too bad altogether.

I do not believe but I should be as much as eight or nine miles from Sunday there!  Here, if there is not a Sabbath generally recognised, there is sort of capacity for making one for one's self; and there are some decent people, good people. some very few, young & old both, in whom I feel interested, & from whom I shall dislike to part. Far fewer & less though than I have found in some places in three months time.

   What sort of a place is Milo really? And what is it going to be?  "Elijah Severance" that was the Teamster? it was a strange suicide.  lived down between the rivers. 
 You did not write in your last letter any thing about the "Folks". the little ones etc. Almeda & her Children.
  Did I tell you Cousin Joseph was at work with me, on the Rail Road?  I like Joseph much & his wife too.
 I hope you will write again soon & frequently                                                           Aff. I.S.

Why cannot some of the rest write too.
Completed

[written upside down]Are you going to spend the winter at Milo or Bangor Mother?

I.S.M. Grouts                                                                         "Grouts" Nov. 13th 1848
 Nov. 14, 1848                                                                                      Isaac

Dear Mother

    Your last letter lies before me. From the date it seems that it was written about a month ago. It is however little more than a week since I received it; it probably waited by the way some at Bangor or Hampden, and then as I had changed my residence, it was most a week after it arrived at Northfield probably before I obtained it.  I believe I have written to you once since your letter was written though I suppose you had not then received it. I guess I wrote before they moved me off here to Grout's: perhaps about the time I was thinking about Alabama! I guess I wrote all that story. Well Leonard went off to Alabama, & I was promoted to his place. No slight mark of confidence to be placed in a young Engineer, only a year old! to put him in such a situation.   It wasn't a very pleasant situation to begin with though. It is never a very easy business getting into another man's shoes. Engineering is perhaps most difficult of all business for that: and to Cap the Climax Leonard was about as hard a man to follow as could be found. I expect they put me here thinking I could along with it if anybody could! but I assure you it was a hard case for a spell. Much as ever I couldn't sleep a'nights for a week or two. I could not dream of anything else. However patience diligence perseverance etc. etc. are bringing order out of chaos in some measure, & the prospect is now pretty fair of getting along quite comfortably this winter: though I maybe a good deal hurried & perhaps worried for a month or two.
Completed

As for Politics, your letter was so long delayed, it did not reach me until just about Election time; If it had come sooner, I should certainly have written off as fast as possible to Charles upon that subject, for it really hurt my feelings considerable that a brother of mine should aid in the Election of such a man as Zachary Taylor. To be sure, it is no more than we must expect, that the thousands will be led around by by the nose, by party leaders, but then we do not like to see our friends served so. It is really astonishing to see what power over the multitude some of these old party prejudices, obsolete part watchwords, and such ideas as this "must keep out Cas" etc. do have. I hardly know which is the worst for the many to be so blinded & gulled, and by those too who will laugh at them for it when it is over; or for such men as Webster 'understanding the whole so fully, seeing the crime & the cheat, even acknowledging it so plainly: to be so driven in, whipped in, or as many say, absolutely bought & bribed in, to the support, of it can be called support, of a party; to so eat his own words, almost to eat himself.

  It is astonishing what money can do - even with Genius, especially when it happens to be poor as Webster is.

One other thing, as for this "Must have Taylor or Cass." I would certainly very much prefer Cass to Taylor. You could hardly find a Mass. Whig who would not except for this one thing. Taylor is the Whig 'so called' Candidate; forty thousand it seems did not care even for that.

To be sure I regard Cass as equally unprincipled as Taylor,  but then I can but put infinitely more confidence in his future course. With all such men conducts depends upon influences, as true as ethics. Cass is a Northern Man, New England born, always a Northman; necessarily under Northern influences.
Completed

Taylor is the contrary exactly: his whole life, character, conduct, opinion, principles expressed & implied, all exactly opposite. He is necessarily a very different man on the Slavery question from Clay or Crittenden or Clayton, from Kentucky, Tennessee, Virginia men, from any southern men except South Carolina or Louisiana men. Any others might be trusted.

  Who is that Mrs. Gilman's Physician? My opinion is, even if he be Dr. Kimball, that he ought to be prosecuted. Even with no more force than he has, it would be in his power to do differently. 
 It is a fact that your Children, Mother, are rather lucky. To be sure the world considers luck to be merely making money. But I mean being fortunate, prospered in whatever one undertakes. Just think how I have got along in Engineering, considering my beginning, without favor, patronage, influence or any thing. Circumstances have all seemed to work together just exactly right to give me the best chance to learn to do,  and to do all kinds of business; And then now just the right vacancy to occur right before me, and confidence enough placed in me to just crowd me right up into it and sustain one there.  Before, as Leveller all along back, I have had the work to do, with somebody else behind me to tell me how to do it, and to be responsible for it. Now I am to go on and do it myself and tell others how to do it.  Mr. Field when he comes along down here now does not tell me what to do as he used to, but asks me how I am going to have such a peice of work done; what I am going to put here or there, or advises me what to do. Now I am fairly an "Engineer"

There is some care about it though more than I used to have. I do not, nor do others, find Assistants to take of the care quite as much as I did from Mr. Field last spring & Summer. There is some responsibility in having the work of so many different kinds or 2 or 3 hundred men dependent on one.
Completed

Nov. 13th. I got a big letter from Bangor today. Joseph, Lucy & Samuel. I haven't heard from Anne yet since she reached Racine, expect to soon. Lucy had a letter just before she wrote to me.

 Lucy & Samuel have taken it into their heads to give me abundant advice to the effect "get married"! What is it best to do about it? They like it so well they think every body else must. The trouble is, they go only half way. their advice is too general. they say "Marry": the question is "whom?" Lucy leaves me very much in doubt whether her preference would be for Olive Furber, or Lizzie Doe! What do you think of her taste? I do not know but my taste would be rather a hard one to suit: though after all I am a little inclined to think that there is not so much difference: that whoever the parties, the fault is one's own if not suited in the end. Characters are moulded to the circumstances & companions they meet with, in great measure, spite of Story & romance.
      As respects Society & every thing of that kind, my position is certainly very far from favorable: it was bad enough at Northfield Since I came down here I have gone up to Northfield on Sabbath 9 miles, on Sat. night: but believe I shall go over to Montague only, 4 miles in future mostly. 
 My present Post Office Direction is "Grouts" on Grouts Corner, Mass. 

Perhaps I better not tell you what sort of a place it is: nor how the Tavern, our boarding house, has 50 boarders, 20 beds, & a Dining Room that seats 15! However I am very comfortable. "The Engineer" has a large room, perhaps the last in the house. It is R.R. Office, filled of course with Drawing tables, books, tools & paper, & has two beds, one for me, one for my two Assistants. But you know we do as we choose, furnish us or room with whatever we like, & Vt. & Mass. pays the bills! The great thing for me, plenty of best Sperm Candles.
One thing Grouts is better than Northfield; it has no idlers. 
Do write soon, frequently, often.
Love to All,
Write me about all.   JJvJ?  Aff. I.S.M. JJ.?
Completed

I.S.M. Grouts                                                                                                              Isaac 
Dec. 10, 1848                                                                           Grouts Dec. 10th, 1848.
Dear Mother 

                                 Your excellent letter was duly & gratefully received yesterday. Being stuck here at Grouts not very well, a rainy Sunday etc. I have been writing to Anne, from whom I received a nice letter yesterday and to Lucy who I suppose likely by this time is at Milo to spend the winter mostly. To prevent me from doing or feeling worse I believe I will continue the business by beginning at least a letter to you.
 As for you apprehensions of evil in my behalf, I guess there is little reason. The "Glory" of being at Grouts I should hardly think could injure any one. As for health, it is very possible that since being here, I may have somewhat overworked body or rather Mind, and am just now feeling the natural reaction. At any rate I feel rather dull stupid & sleepy for a day or two. I expect I have got the Jaundice a bit. Notice that I look about as yaller as a yellow dog today, and about as dull as a  beetle.

this Jaundice is a disease indigeneous to this Miserable Miller's River. At any rate prevalent here. something perhaps in the soil, air, or water. I do not like the place.  

  Ann certainly seems to be very comfortable & happy in her new & far off situation. I judge from her letter that as a Teacher She has a better situation than she ever has had before. Says her school is more pleasant & less
Completed

laborious than any school she was ever engaged in. her place & society every way pleasant & desirable.
Is it not different from your & even from some of her own gloomy anticipations. The fact is this "looking for evil", & tormenting one's self with "ills that never happened," is rather foolish, as you say. I believe it is hardly reckoned among my numerous follies. So it will do for me to object to it in others

 You enquire about Grouts. It is in the limits of the town of Montague, whose a corner of that comes up to Millers River, a mile or two from its Mouth.  It was a place where a little dirty bridge was thrown over the noisy stream, or road branched off to Wendell, & a man named Martin Grout, a German I guess had stuck in page is folded = little ..little lone spot just big enough for them  between the sharp pine hills, & called it tavern.
  Well- the Vt. & Mass. R.R. came twisting along down the crooked rocky, precipitous banks & bed of Miller's river, where nothing else ever could have got, hardly even a fox, for he couldn't take quite so long jumps from side to side; Expending some several hundred thousand dollars on & around this spot Making a level plain out of the hills a hundred feet high, building bridges etc. Sicking down here & there Depots, Engine, Freight, Water & Wood houses of all sorts 8 or ten. R.R. tracks of various forms & directions, one to Northfield & Brattleboro, one to Greenfield etc. besides through or beside all the multifarious buildings built or to be built here. In short make a great Rail Road Station, Watering place etc. out of it. Such is Grouts - as it now is.
Completed

Your suggestion not to "get married" till I get away from Grouts, is certainly to the point, & well founded. I presume that it will be strictly followed: though my predecessor got married here! to a sister of the tavernkeeper's wife who waited on the tables ignorant & coarse too. but so was he in many respects.
Really though I begin to "take it to heart", among the Multitude of Councilors. Not only Lucy & Samuel, I could get round that; but you & Joseph, and now even Anne, away from Wisconsin.  What shall I do about it.
The fact is; (I do not know but I am little too nice about it: as my misfortune has always been in every thing else to have my tastes far above my means) but I really do not know of any body that I want. There may be some that want me: but that is quite a different matter.  There was a young lady in Turner that I could have liked considerable, perhaps did; but she was engaged to a young Engineer before I ever saw her; a friend of mine, and I couldn't in honor "cut him out," as the chaps say. They are Married, a year since, I couldn't go to the wedding: was? in N.H. He is Sec. Eng. on the Portsmouth & Concord R.R. She is a grand woman, & one of the best friends I have got any where. She had a sister younger & prettier I suppose than "Nancy"; who was perhaps designed for me: A very good girl too: but then I never liked her as well as she me. I never repented much more of any little accident, than I have of kissing her cheek one particular time. It hurt me when I heard how she cried when I did not go back to Turner to teach the next Fall.

 I do not know as there is any body else in all "Down East" that I care much for. Josephine of Topsham too, whom Anne once recommended to me, was engaged to my particular friend Morse, before I ever met with her.

I have certainly met no very "bright particular" Star since I have been in Mass. If I was most obliged to choose from so limited a field, I should feel rather sick. I guess it would have to be that Miss Dutton you perhaps saw when you were at Northfield. I guess she isn't but 17 years old, perhaps 18. She is  a good girl though and I like her folks first rate.  There, I believe I have made a "clean breast" on the subject of "Matrimony"! Pleas you & Lucy laugh at it , & I will ----
Completed

I am very much obliged to you for the News about Milo. I have considered you all very negligent on that respect, and perhaps have wrote to you to that effect. Now Lucy has got back to Milo, I shall expect to hear from her, "all the particulars" how it seems to her after her absence etc. N.B.
I wondered you did not stay longer at Hampden, get fairly rested before venturing back to that Milo again. Perhaps you will be wiser next time you get there.
Lucy I guess those shirts are just the thing, though I not get them washed yet so as to try them wear them  I wonder if Spruce Gum isn't good for the Jaunders.
Joseph A.S. worked with me till I came down here.
Very possible he may come dob here now some. ? Holton is laid up. I hear today Rufus is better, setting up; and which encourages me much, Miss Harriet Snow of Bernardston, his Ladye Love, is there to take care of him. It will do him good 'like a Medicine' doubtless.

  Joseph & Jane call the Babe - fact I hardly know-- Susan, I guess, or Susan Jane. I call it "little one." It is fat as two pigs & healthy as three or four.
 What did that Mr. Ricker Man give for Crockett lot? Is it a Ricker that used to live over Pleasant River, or a "New Man"?
Do Write Write Now you & Lucy are both at Milo you can afford to write as Lucy at least promised as often as I would. Aff. I.S.M.

Your letter directed I.S.M. "Engineer"  Perhaps that is my title, but I share it with another. The "Engine Man" whoever has the care of a Steam Engine is always perhaps properly called "Engineer"  His business is quite different from ours thought we may set him to work. Ours is "Civil Engineering" I am Civ. Eng. or Engineer
Completed

I.S.M. Goffstown                                                                                           Isaac

June 17, 1849                                                                           Goffstown N.H. June 17th 1849
Dear Mother

                        It seems to me I do not hear from you very often lately: and when you do write, it is too often only a few lines, on the corner of a letter. When I was at Warwick, Uncle Joseph complained of you for not writing, and accused you of "getting lazy". I took it upon myself to deny the charge quite indignantly: but I do not know but I shall be obliged to "retract". if you do not write to me better than lately. To be sure I do not know but I am partly to blame myself. Not being an "original genius" or having like Joseph any original ideas. I can only write letters by answering the letters of others. Of course my letters are apt to be directed to those who wrote to me last. 

I believe I have been a pretty punctual correspondent to Joseph and Lucy who wrote to me usually pretty punctually.

 I have not much to write now that will be of interest. The life of an Engineer, though to be sure full of variety, is of that kind of Minute Variety that hardly bears copying or transferring to a letter. Perhaps it would be called a monotonous variety. 

One may ride or walk a few miles farther one day than another meet a few more folks, or be a little more hurried, quarrel with a contractor or agent one day, and find him good natured and obsequious the next; but it is all hardly worth telling of.

 I am really rather pleasantly situated here this summer. I have charge of about a dozen miles of Rail Road now in process
Completed

of construction. It is mostly an easy line, and principally Located, & the work laid out by myself, so that I have less trouble & vexation from other people's business than I had last Fall & Winter at Grouts. My Cheif comes up perhaps once a week, just passes by to the other Division, but rarely does or meddles with any thing, or asks any questions if I send in my regular reports. He seems to have got the idea that I can get along pretty well myself, and if I go to him for advise about any thing generally advises, "Do as you think best".  So you see I am "independent" & "responsible" to my heart's content. The independence agrees first rate, but the responsibility galls a little some times, especially where business differs from any I ever had charge of before.

 I think I am extremely fortunate in my Assistants. I did expect to have as my Leveller or first Assistant a young man, who was on the Vt. & Mass. when I first went there, and then above me. I rather think I could have got along pretty well with him, but I dreaded it much for he is one of the rudest sort, very profane, and though a very capable young man, always had the reputation of being very hard to get along with: But I contrived get him on the Third Division, and got here with me I think one of the best young men I know any thing about. Edward Everett of Winsor Vt. Son of Hon. Horace Everett late U.S. Senator from Vermont, and a Young Man of Family, Character, and Education. A Graduate of the University of Vermont, since then is trying to be an Engineer in right Earnest. He is an Episcopalian, is a gentleman & a scholar, I regard it as worth a great deal to me to have such a man with me, not only for his help in my
Completed

business, but for the benefit of his society & companionship which I need. I have always suffered for the lack of such society. I did so especially at Northfield & Grouts. Society of the other Sex, I have none really. My LandLady I cannot like much As Landlady she is first rate, a fine table & orderly house but she is selfish coarse and loud, though taking much pains to please her boarders.

  I have seen, I believe in N.Y. Papers, the account a "Mrs. Bagley of Milo, Piscataquis Co, Maine" shooting an enormous Eagle just carrying off one of her Sons! Is there any such story, and what is it, and where does it belong?
 Do you know any thing of the whereabouts of a young man named J.M. Metcalf? I have ordered him to appear here forthwith, but he does not as yet show himself, or say when he will. If he has taken refuge with you, or is harboured in your region, I wish you would send him along here immediately.  I will do him good when he gets here, riding around the country etc. etc. I usually ride 15 to 20 miles per day. Keep the use of one horse all the time. and can have another when I want, and will if he will come.

The R.R.Co. Allows me $1500 per Month extra for Horse Hire.
Speaking above of female society, there is one Lady in Goffstown I intend to get acquainted with if possible. She is an Old Maid probably 40 years old, is wealthy, highly educated, accomplished, travelled, and moreover has been extremely beautiful, has the most magnificent & sweetest eye I ever saw, and I form a very high opinion of her from her Sabbath School Class.
Completed

[left-hand side] I dont think I feel
The Minister here is a brother of Austin Willey, Editor of the Maine Anti Slavery Standard; was a Class Mate, I think Room Mate of Swan Lyman Pomroy at Andover. He is a man of Sound & well furnished mind, writes really superior sermons; is a very good man, all say; still I am afraid he mistook his vocation. He is not an interesting preacher, & is by no means popular with his hearers. He cannot adapt himself to them, especially in Society; He is not, and cannot be, acquainted with them. I think he might be really interesting among those with whom he can feel communion. He told me he had not much sympathy of feeling with his parishioners.
He is a Widower, and just to be married again soon. He has been rather unfortunate I judge in his children.

  My Landlady has two children, a little boy & girl, and makes a fool of herself and her son by loving him so much better than she does her daughter.
  Cousin Joseph Stevens is prospering first rate at Grouts, Depot Master, Wood Agent etc. Has been reported as the best manager Depot in the Line. He has gone somewhat into trade too, in Some heavy articles, Lime, Plaster, Flour. Wrote me he cleared $10.00 an Hour & Plaster trade in one week. I wrote to him of Charles' Second Son. He wrote "If such occurrences are like to be frequent, pray advise him to emigrate to some better country; if the potatoe crop should fail there...."
Well I believe I have made quite a Letter of this  I hope you will write soon & abundantly, good old fashioned Letters.
                                                                                                        Affectionately  I.S.
Completed

Goffstown July 16th 1849

Dear Mother,    

               I believe I have not yet answered your excellent letter of June 26.  Seems to me if you only knew how much good your letters do you would write oftener.  As for my coming home, the matter is uncertain. Still I do mean to get away if possible in August.  I worked so well along in the Spring that I do not have to be so much hurried now a days. I can get along pretty easy, considerable care, but not a great deal to do at present except Office Work, and riding about to give directions and see that they are done right in all respects. I can not get away now on account of some Masonry which require constant looking after to have it done right. If I get that fixed up right after the First of August Work is done up, if nothing else comes up which is probably, perhaps I can get away for a week.
 As for Joseph, I think he reads writes & thinks too much. Why can he not be contented to simply enjoy life without vexing his brain for any thing just for one season Load round, ride about and lie in the sun not read & write all the time. It is a great pity he could not come. I would have taken care of him good.
The Weather here has been extremely hot, and very dry ground all parched up.  Hay only half a crop. Corn very backward for cold weather in June now looks as black, as you please, & grows like every thing
Completed

I had a nice long letter from Anne, the other day: but as she mentioned having just written to you, I suppose you have all the news I could write.
Lucy, I suppose likely has gone back to Hampden. Her Letter thankfully received . I am about writing to her at Hampden.
In haste
I.S.M. Goffstown
July 16, 1849
[upside down] Isaac

                     Goffstown July 16, 1849
Completed

" Parker's." West Goffstown, N.H.
                                                                                                               Oct. 22. 1849

Dear Mother,

     It is night, and Everett has gone to bed. I sit here in my comfortable room thinking of home, dear home, and the loved ones there.

How I long to look in upon your quiet circle, and talk with Joseph, and enquire of all his health.
I do want to go home, but do not know when I can get away. I am confined here close enough at present. I have a Report, Plan & Estimates of the Survey to make out, which I find is no small task.
Even if I should succeed in crowding through that, there is getting to be quite a pressure of other business accumulating upon my hands: the Final Settlements with the Contractors and varied other matters which Everett did not dare to undertake, and which have been growing these two or three months.
At any rate I intend to come home; so you can expect: but mind not to get impatient, or look for me: if I do not come till Spring Even.
I believe, Mother, I write this letter, not because I have any thing particular to say or write; but mainly to enquire why you do not write to me. Really Mother, it is quite a while since I have seen one of your good old fashioned letters. Joseph writes, and you  you perhaps stick in a bit in one corner somewhere;
Completed

but it will hardly do to call such a letter.

I think you ought to do better. There are enough other younger people in the world to do the work mostly; and you should sit & read & talk to Joseph, and write letters to your Children, when you are not going to visit them. give them your good advice. and let them have the benefit of your experience. Before I get to be of your age, I intend to have my council & advice of more advantage and benefit to the world than all my work is now; and I think it is the same in your case now. "Old Men for Council, Young men for War" is as true as it ever was.  

I am anxious to hear about Lucy's housekeeping arrangements for this winter. I am a little inclined to think that you & Joseph had better spend the winter with her, had you not? some considerable part of it at least. Care must be taken for Joseph's travelling about though.  he must not travel in the Stage or in Charles' jolting Wagon. but in an easy proper carriage and by short stages a little ways at a time; so as by all means to avoid fatigue: if necessary not make the whole journey in one day. In this way, I presume the journey would do him good rather than injury.

 Is your health good this Fall? I am afraid you had too much of fatigue and care, with sickness in the house & care of Joseph & all.

My health is superexcellent. I lost weight some while. out on the survey, worked down; but, came back toughened and strong as you please, and now am forthcoming up like a hog.  If you shouldn't know me!
Completed

Our Minister here at Goffstown is sick; has a long Typhoid Fever. I watch with him a week since, & probably will again. 
There is no Meeting during his illness; so we have to stray off to the neighboring towns to Church.
The town next north of Goffstown, Dunbarton, is one of the best places I know of. There is not a Farm, a store, or a Lawyer in the Town and it is a year since here has been any such thing as Town's Poor, if indeed there ever was.  The whole population turn out en mass to Church. A meeting house nearly twice as large as the Goffstown  House, which is never half full, is there always full of attentive hearers, and about the best looking more intelligent audience I ever saw. The Congregationalist Church there has never had but two Ministers. The first ordained when the Town was first settled, died full of years & usefulness some 12 or 15 years since, and the present excel considerable Mr. Putnam was settled in his place. 
You know the Riders of Brownville: they originated in Dunbarton. One Brother still lives there one of the best men anywhere. He owns some land down on our R.R. Line in Weare, and the first time I saw him I said that man's name must be Rider from his resemblance to the Riders of Brownville.
Nov. 2d 1849.  I have been expecting this fortnight to hear letters from some of you, but as they do not come to hand I will send this after them. Do write.  P.S. I went to Boston Monday, and right back. No Special news here.  It has been very arm has just become very cold.  Aff. in haste

                                                                                                                                                                                             I.S.M.
Completed

Goffstown Nov. 9. 1849

Dear Mother

     Why do you not write to me? Now Joseph is gone, I can see no possible reason why you cannot write often. When he was at home we supposed you had considerable to do to take care of him, and made that an excuse for not writing.  Joseph's going away to Waterford was really quite unexpected to me. To be sure he made something about it, but I hardly though he was in earnest: until the first I knew of it, I received a letter from Waterford. He has written to me twice since he arrived there. He bore the journey it seems much better than I had supposed he would. In fact, I believe he & Eliab, (from whom I have just heard) both think the journey did him good. I guess he finds himself very pleasantly situated at Waterford, and with some very pleasant acquaintances, especially  that Mr. Isaiah Dole, Joseph's old Teacher at Foxcroft, whom he liked so well, you know 

I got a letter from him yesterday. He says he doesn't hardly dare to say certain, but has a notion that he can perceive an improvement since he has been there.
Completed

I wish I could get away to go there and visit him while there but it hardly seems possible for me to get away at present.

  A letter from Lucy lately. She says they are going to move into the Hawthorne house, instead of the one they first intended; Which must certainly ne quite an improvement in many respects.  I think it is a fine situation.

Lucy says you are going to stay with her a long time when she gets to keeping house. So I expect when I get down East again I shall find you there.
My health is excellent. I have got as fat as you please since I got back from the Survey. There is no news here; the principal topic of thought & conversation still being the miserable poverty of the New Hampshire Central RailRoad Corporation and all connected with it.  The Corporation must be now owing me considerably over three hundred dollars.
It is very rainy day indeed today, so we are confined to the house entirely and I am now writing this letter not because I have any thing at all to write, but merely because I want to hear from you.
It seems a great while since I have had a letter from you. How Many times have I written
Completed

to Milo since you wrote to me?
Our Minister has got most well of his Fever, not enough so however to preach yet, but his pulpit is now supplied by neighboring ministers.
There are many sick about here. Fevers Typhoid Fevers I believe they are called are prevailing considerably. Two or three about here where I board are about sick with very bad colds etc.

  I will not send this letter because I really think it is worth sending, but because I think the writing it may do me as much good as the postage.  
  One item of News I forgot almost. I went to Boston the other day. Only just went down & right back on business.

I do want to hear from you, all. How has Almeda's lame foot got along. and how are all the children?
Love to all. My time gets short.

                                                                     Aff.  I.S.
Completed

I.S.M. Goffstown
Nov. 13 1849

                                                                                                                                          Goffstown, N.H. Nov. 13. 1849.

My Dear Mother

                             I received your kind and excellent letter yesterday. You cannot imagine how much good your letter do me; if you did you would write oftener than you usually do lately.
   I am afraid from your letter that you are very lonesome since Joseph has gone away.
 Now I do not think you do just right about it.

I suppose you shut yourself up there with Albina, and hardly see any one else once a week, living in a perfect monotony varied only by reading till your eyes ache.  I do not know but it is wrong. Scripture says it is not good for man to be alone, and all experience proves conclusively that Society is necessary to mankind; necessary to the proper health, happiness, & development of mind & feeling.

 Moreover in your case it is not right to shut yourself up there alone: for the benefit which you might do to others: that you know is the true object of life: We have no right to live for ourselves alone. Just think now how much real good it would do. Mrs. Henry Sargent, and him too, for you to go over there and spend the day. They would feel better and be better and happier for a week. I really think they are good people
Completed

And do you not believe you yourself would be full as happy and comfortable for spending a day in such a manner with Mrs. Sargent. or up with Mrs. Lee, or even with Mrs. Furber.
Or a nice friendly call upon some of the Younger Ladies, Ellen Brown or Angella Everett. How much good it would do them. Hardly any thing is in reality so agreeable or so profitable to the Young as the kindness and interest shown in them by the Old. I do believe the benefit to yourself would be great. A constant brooding upon our own personal cares, troubles, or even joys, injures any one. Self corrodes self; its cares sort of eat their place into the heart. While on the contrary a partaking tje cares, troubles, or joys of others is rather a benefit. It expands the heart, and does not in reality increase ones own sorrow while it divides that of another.
There - is not that quite a Lecture to my Mother?  I hope you will give me one twice as long upon some of my shortcomings to pay me for it.
I did not get fairly through with mine though. I meaned to say also something about your being disposed when you read it, to say "cant": you cant get started.  Why not?  It would really do Charles good, besides being a pleasure to him, to carry you up to Brownville, or wherever you want to go.
Completed

I suppose Lucy & Samuel will soon, if indeed they have not already done so, move into the Hawthorne house. When they get to housekeeping I suppose you will go and make them a nice visit. It would be hardly fair not to, and I know you would enjoy yourself there with them. You will meet Joseph there when he come back, and I am not quite sure that both of you had not better spend the Winter there. Do you not think that it would be better for him?

Joseph you know feels somewhat encouraged that he is improving at Waterford. He is certainly more pleasantly situated there than I expected. I presume the journey and the company are really beneficial to him. You seemed to think he was not? better than when he went away, because his limbs were weaker. I regarded that as favorable: the lameness in his back was "scattering" of course his limbs would be temporarily worse; Would not that be natural?
It is very uncertain about my being able to go Down East this Fall. I have written to Joseph to let me know when he gets ready to go home, and if I can possibly get away I will go on there and accompany him to Portland, if I can go no further. Perhaps I can go clear home. By the way, pray do not worry about my working too hard nowadays.  At present I have some of
Completed

the easiest times you please. I cannot very easily get away much to be sure; but my occupation is little but riding about to see that all things go on just right. By & by when the Track Laying get along to my own Division I shall have more work to do myself.
Bow, is sort of "between hat & grass" here.

 I believe you did not write any thing about Almeda and the Children. You do not shut yourself up so as not even to see them do you! I want to hear about them. Almeda has recovered from her lameness, has she not?

I have not heard from Sister Anne for a long time.
Do your spectacles fit your Eyes exactly?
Ought you not to get the glasses changed occasionally?
I wish I could come home just to show you how fat I am; and my whiskers!

  Well, I guess I have written nonsense enough for one time.
  Do write to me      Affectionately 
                                                            I.S.
Completed

Goffstown Dec. 2d, 1849  N.H.

Dear Mother

   Your letter I received a little less than a week since. Of course it did me a good deal of good, and I wanted to write again as soon as I could, so as to get another one like it, before a great while.  You want I should come home and stay "a good long while." Now I do not think you had better wish quite so. In order to be at home a good long while, I must be out of business. And to be out of business is the worst thing I could have. My business is a very good one as long as I have enough of it; but it is good for nothing if I am out of business you know. I have been extremely successful so far in finding business. I am only afraid my good success in this respect will not continue long.

To be sure I want to go home, as much probably as any of you can want me to, but we can not always have all our wants, and I suppose I must be contented if I have constant employment and get a chance to go home one or two weeks in a year. For the rest, you must come and see me when I cannot leave business. {I shall have to get married some of these years to have a chance to receive visitors} and I must be satisfied with letters, from home instead of visits there.
Completed

To tell the truth however, there is considerable prospect that I may be out business some part of the Winter, and have time enough to go home.

 You say you think you had not better be at Hampden very long. Why not? I really believe it would be better for you besides doing Lucy good, to stay there a good while. I think you are apt to get too moping & dull there at Milo, with only Albina, & need Lucy etc, to keep up your spirits. You know that "Lecture" I wrote the other time, about Society.  I suppose when I begin upon my subject I say so much, that you have generally got in the habit of thinking it all does not mean any thing at all. I expect it is a bad habit of mine, but I really think myself there is at least a grain of truth in it sometimes.  You say you are "growing Old". Now I suppose that Society is really much more absolutely essential to the old , that to the Young.
  I am very glad to hear that they are getting along so well in finishing off that East Room. I hope it will soon be done up in shape. I think there had better not be any Close Stove in the room, perhaps a Franklin or something of the kind. I believe it is decided to be a fact that no kind of Close Stove can be as healthy as open fires, especially for the sick. Joseph will probably want to be there this Winter. Will he not? Or do you think he had better stay at Bangor, or Hampden with Lucy? His complete recovery you know must be the Work of time.
Completed

I do not know as I have any news to write about.
Had a letter recently from Cousin Joseph A.S.  They are very well, and anxious to see me there. I have been wanting to go back there for some time: thought I would go a Thanksgiving time, last week, just the day, but we were laying track & putting up Depot buildings and I could not get away. Joseph is doing first rate on the Rail Road, has all the charge of Freight on the Branch, and two or three to help him. I presume is pretty well paid. He is trying to get me back there this Winter if they finish building the Branch.  Folks all well.

 I have not heard from Anne for a long time. Did you have a Thanksgiving at Milo?

Nov. 4th I intended to finish this Letter and send it yesterday, but we had a great snowstorm, and I did not get out to the Post Office: but was busy "in Office" all day.  
It was the first snow of the season: perhaps 6 inches of it, and I judge it will make pretty good sleighing if it stays on.

  I was thinking yesterday, while going over calculations and settling up final estimates for contractors, that I had got pretty near closing up my business here; and can soon get through, if they do not succeed in pushing the Rail any further. So that perhaps you may expect me home sometime before a great while. But I cannot stop to write more now, So good bye. & do write soon
                                                                              Affectionately
                                                                                              I.S.M.
Completed

I.S.M.    Goffstown
Jan. 5, 1851                                                                             Goffstown, N.H. Jan. 5, 1850
Dear Mother

   I received your kind letter yesterday I think after expecting it a good while. Of course I need not say how much good "Mother's Letter" always do me.
 I am really glad to hear that you are going to Hampden, for I do believe that you will enjoy a visit there. I am by no means sure that you ought not to spend most of your time with Lucy. You could not help being happier with her than with Albina.  If so you certainly should; for I know of nothing in the World to confine you in any place, but where your children are. I believe you think you are growing old. Now I think moving about is much more essential for Old folks than for the young: they ought to spend their time mostly in visiting their children.
 Did you ever hear of an old proverb that Mothers always like their daughter's husbands better than their Son's wives? Isn't it somewhat true?

If so you had better live with Lucy much of the  time until I get married. But I intend some time to get a wife so superlatively super excellent you will be so pleased with her as to want to live with us most all of the time! I hope you will not be too impatient for the time to come! for I hardly know where to find her yet, and I want of course to be very sure.
Completed

About Joseph, I agree with you entirely that he is too apt to adhere to the advice of his physicians rather than to consult his own feelings: Moreover I do think that Douchs injurious to him, and I wrote to him immediately to that effect; I guess he thought so himself.
I am quite flattered to find that this great German Doctor, who is really celebrated, coincides with me in the course of treatment he recommends for Joseph.  quiet, freedom from fatigue, gentle applications of Water. If he does stay there at Waterford, I think Joseph had better by all mean remain there, perhaps for a year. If Dr. Munde does not stay there, I have very little opinion of Prescott, and I want Joseph to return to Milo or Hampden, remain, quiet, pursue the Water treatment very gently, and wait.
I repeat, as I have always done, that his cure must be effected by rest, quiet, and by time.

 I have lately heard of two cases of injury to the spine, apparently worse originally than Joseph's, which by mere time without treatment, Eventually recovered.  A Nephew of Putnam of Dunbarton many years since, was totally disabled bu an injury to the back worse than Joseph's; was two or three years unable to move his limbs at all, at least half a dozen years unable to do anything at all, but gradually recovered, and  fully, so that he is now one of the smartest men there is any where.  I regret more than every thing the violent treatment to which Joseph was first subjected; as just so much retarding his cure.
Completed

I went off Dec. 28 round to Mass. Montague & Northfield, and staid over Sabbath. I did not go to Warwick or Royalston. I had not time. Saw Uncle Joseph at Northfield. They are very well this Winter and sound. Joseph is doing first rate on the Rail Road, acquiring a grand reputation, and doing well every way. 
I went round there to see about business. I shall probably leave here before long. At the rate they are like to progress on this road, there is little object for me to stay. I was privately assured the other day that if Mr. Chase, our Cheif Engineer, had concluded to leave, I should have been requested to take his place! by that would have been ridiculous for one of my limited experience. However according to present appearances, there can be little forMr. Chase & I both to do here, and I had better leave. I am offered a place where they are just going ti complete that Branch of the Vt. & Mass. road into Greenfield but it is not what I want, only two or three miles of Road, and little to do.  I do not know but I may go upon that celebrated Troy & Greenfield R.R. I hate too. There could perhaps be no better chance for my advancement, than on that Road, but it is an ill country, and farther off. I should probably have to  go into New York State, or Extreme Western Mass. or Vt. so I dread it. I am expecting to hear this week.

 I wish I could get a good situation on a Maine R.R. but unfortunately I have no influence in that quarter. One must go where he can. And I ought to be thankful to be able to keep in New England or Northern States.
Completed

Hannah Parson, did you know had lost another infant. and Albert & Maria though well as usual, are by no means rugged. Ardelia's oldest son is very ill lame, fever sore or something for a long time.
Coz Maria teaches school & boards at home.
The Northfield Churches are both very well repaired, new furnaces etc. The Unitarians very much pleased with their new Minister. Mr. Wm. Field of Northfield committed suicide, hung himself in Church Shed last week. My Rufus Holton, (did you see him when at Northfield?) is married, and very well, and I am glad.

 Cousin Joseph's business has increased so that he has one other clerk beside Humphrey all the time. He speculates profitably too on Corn, Flour, lime & plaster.
  My health is as good as can be, 15 lbs heavier than last summer. Not a great deal to hurry me. Finishing up my business by day and going visiting by Evening.

I believe I have written you about my visit to Lowel to all the folks.

                                                                                                                  Aff I.S.M.

Lucy, it is well for you to care how you may please your husband, I believe the bible does not forbid it, but pray do not forget all the rest of the world; and especially remember to write to me. do. "be good." If I had a New Year's present for you you may get it soon after I get through here. Do write to me about Eliab, if he will not write to me.

                                        Good bye all I.S.M.
Completed

Here.   June 2d 1850

Dear Mother & Lucy,

    I do not know but we ought to have written last week, but you know that things there go on so still and straight that there is not much to write about: and then besides it must be remembered that this is with farmers a very busy season of the year!

The Valise and letters came safe to hand Friday night and gladdened us much. We expect Lucy will get well enough by last of this week, or first of next, to come up here with you and stay quite a spell to recruit her health.

  Joseph has left Homeopathy, and partly Hydropathy, and now makes vigorous and frequent assaults upon a big earthen pan full of syrup & sarsaparilla which I have prepared, besides munching an occasional sprig of Pipsissewa, to say nothing of figs & Maple Sugar which Eliab sent up; and just now a Juniper limb. You will readily perceive that in most of these I can afford him some assistance so as to get along faster and better, and we expect to have him get well right away.
 Moreover sine the Botany Books came up he is going into the study & examinations of Plants & flowers right and left diligently. In this last we especially want the presence and cooperation of Lucy, whom we hereby request you to bring up as soon as may be convenient.  {N.B. perhaps she might also assist us somewhat in some of the before mentioned operations upon Sarsaparilla, pipsissewa, figs, Sugar & Juniper}
Completed

You write Mother about sending up for Lucy to do housework etc.   

 The East part of the house is by some mysterious agency constantly cleansed purified and put in better order than it has had the habit of, every morning before the people of the house are up, which is pretty early, or thereabouts, sometimes.
 I talk some of offering to contract to do the rest of the housework, cooking etc. for the family and household. I rather think I could spare a couple of hours per diem from my multifarious occupations, to attend to that branch also.
 I notice sometimes that these things seem to worry the individual who now performs them.
 To be sure, one day when she went off visiting singing meeting or something, I came near getting wound up in it myself: One of my subjects called Charley being left by her in a remarkably cross, fretful & sickish state. However I finally drugged him with ' lasses and got him to sleep, did the same by Joseph & Mr. Temple who was then present, and then went off to ploughing in the field.

A letter from Sister Elisabeth Anne Racine was received at this place on Friday Eve last. It was directed to A. M. Metcalf, but being to the care of C.W. Rich; the latter individual "bust em open" and we devoured the contents.

I believe she wrote that she had written much & more too to Lucy lately. So we will hardly copy even .............................Joseph?

Milo, Maine, June 14. 1850

Dearly Beloved Mother & Lucy

    A letter from you long desired and earnestly expected is just now received. And I am very joyfully disposed to write in answer thereunto to send by return of mail tomorrow.
  As for Mother's coming home, do pray put both of your hearts perfectly at rest as to my necessity on demand for her return until you are both of you entirely ready therefor, be it days, weeks, or months.

The only thing we would request of you is to write to us occasionally to let us know of your well being.  That appears to be the only special want we have nowadays not constantly supplied.
At any rate, do not come home without bringing both of you. though with with that Proviso of course the quicker you come the better.

 And my Charge unto you Mother is -- be you careful of that girl Lucy {I do not know but she would like to have me call her Matron, but I wont till she gets well} if she cannot take care of herself. I should have thought most any of you would have known better than to send her to Church. I suppose the truth were to be told the going to Meeting half a day is in reality as hard for an Invalid as to do half a days washing. 

This is supp

Josie and Charlie, I take care of myself of course you will need not be concerned that they are not best taken care of
Lucy- get well slowly and surely, not go about tire & sicken yourself
but get well and come up. How nice we will be. Joseph says bring up your Herbarium.
We will show you great things! {Ye may depend}
Farming. Charles finished off Sowing etc. last week nicely, but this week came very big rain, water rose mostly as high as it has been before over low part of the Intervale, fell down again immediately. May kill some of the oats.
Corn, grain & all sorts of crops are up and growing finely.
And the flowers are about as much as we can manage.
