Isaac June 1851
                                                                        Chester Illinois June 29 1851 Sabbath

Dear Mother   It is a very rainy Sabbath day, in a very strange place. It rains so hard this forenoon that I do not undertake to go a long way for the uncertain prospect of very poor preaching, from an Old School {which I do not like} Presbyterian from Kentucky.  So here I sit in this little old "Chester House" with the Mighty Missippi (it is certainly mighty now) washing to doorstep and porch; and thinking, thinking of you all Down East. How I do want to hear from you. I seems as if it had been several ages since I left Bangor, and I have not heard one word from any of you since I started.  I have been writing to some of you about every week. A fortnight ago from Chicago I sent off quite a package of letters. I wrote some at Springfield a week since but thought I need not send until I get to some fixed point. I mailed a letter to Bangor on the Steamboat Thursday I think, and one to Milo, since I reached Chester.

I am detained here at Chester some three days. My destination is out East of here in Perry Co. some 50 miles or more perhaps from here on the Prairies. I believe I wrote to Eliab and to Milo to direct letters to Locust Hill. Letters so directed will doubtless reach there. It is the name of the place where our head quarters are to be probably; But the name of the Post Office I find is
                                                                Mt. Hawkins, Perry Co. Ill.

The safest direction will probably be to Care of B.G. Roots Esq. Mt. Hawkins, Perry Co. Ill.
The name of the County you know is a essential requisite in the direction here.
Whether I shall stay there more than a Month or so is very uncertain.  I cannot tell how I shall like, or what kind of a situation I shall have. I have to begin with only the promise of $65.00 per Month & expenses. If I stay shall probably have up to 100.  If I find the Climate does not agree with me I shall not stay at any rate. Southern Illinois has sometimes been considered unhealthy,  but it is probably only from the character of its population.  The section where I am going is considered one of the healthiest in the State in all respects.

 I came around here from Caledonia on Thursday last. The Steamer,a very splendid Kentucky Boat, Louisville & St. Louis Packet, "Fawn", broke a shaft about 20 miles below here, and after much delay, creeping along with one wheel, unable from disabled condition to make a landing, put me ashore in a small boat at Midnight, half a mile below the City or Village, every Village is an organized City here. Moreover the flood was over the Highway so as to make it extremely difficult reaching the Village any how. But Mr. N. Cole owner of a steam Flour Mill there
Completed

pumping Water out of his Mill by night, absolutely refused to permit me to try to go up to the Village that night, but took me to his house and treated me to his very best lodging & breakfast with true western hospitality.
Friday, I rode twenty Miles or so horse back, in the Middle of a very hot day too, 9 am. to 4 P.M. 2 or 3 out at M.  You would say enough to use up one completely at the East, one who had not been on a horse for 1/2 doz. years perhaps.
But it did not hurt or tire me at all. They have splendid saddles out here, stuffed and quilted as soft as a Cushion, and then the saddle horses, trained to a gait, sort of Canter, very different from a hard trot.  They ride horseback almost altogether here, single wagons or buggies being very rare, and the roads used almost entirely for two horses very hard footing for one horse in the middle

  I enjoyed the ride very much, beautiful country; part of the way along to high bluffs in sight of Missippi River; Corn 6 to 10 ft. high just travelling out, and  some only just out of the ground, Wheat mostly cut and poorly shooked up in the field.

Abundant orchards, especially of peaches, some cherries. Road sides abounding in big blackberries which I could pick abundantly without dismounting.
However there are some Evils, probably lest the country might be Paradise.
In the bushes every where abound what they call Wood ticks, much like a sheep tick, with a little white spot in the middle, who adhere and bite considerable.  None yet are what they call "jiggers" a little red thing about as big as the point of a Needle, found I learned to my sorrow among blackberry bushes etc. who burrow into or under the skin, occasioning considerable burning itching & pain, and a hard lunch or blotch, like that of a mosquitoe on a stranger, only much more so, and sometimes getting all over one.

 I was going out to Perry Co. Sat. but could not get fairly started and so wait until Monday, which makes rather dull staying here.

Eve. I have not been at Church all day today, in account of the rain, much black Illinois deep mud, long hill to climb etc. In fact I am told there were but 10 out this A.M. and even the minister did not go this P.M.  I have slept most of the time I believe!

   My health is very good. The weather for a week or two past has been about the same as our warmest weather in N.E.  I sweat profusely as usual, and am much of the time very thirsty.  I do not know whether from drinking the river water, from restraining myself from drinking as much as I desire, or from the food of the Country, which is universally most abominably too much salted. The Main article of food is Bacon every where in Illinois, the whole half hog salted & smoked in a side, always very salt. And at public houses, steamboats etc. they make the beef just so salt! And drink Coffee, Coffee in vast quantities strong as lye, three times a day Coffee & Bacon are two necessaries of life to regular sucker. The two skillfully combined make fever & ague I expect.

[at top upside down] It is now June 29. I think it will not do to send this letter till after July 1 and the new Postage Law is in operation. You must write to me when you find out where I am. I believe I shall direct this letter to Bangor expecting that you are there now with Lucy, Mother. Affectionately I.S.
Completed

Du Quoin, March 31, '54

Dear Mother

     I suppose you would have got a letter from us a little sooner if Antoinette had not been unwell.  Moreover I suppose Charles wrote to Milo last Sunday so that you have doubtless heard somewhat of us.

I was away to St. Louis a week or more, on my return a week since found Antoinette quite sick.  Charles perhaps wrote you about her getting frightened. She was probably not quite well: mayhap a little billious and nervous, with a bad headache when the big kitchen Stove fell down with a tremendous crash. Abby was Ironing & little Mayo tied in a little Chair under the store almost. The little fellow
Completed

was really not hurt at all, but had a very narrow escape from fire, stove, stove pipe, big kettle of boiling water etc. etc. was pretty well covered with soot and ashes but unhurt.  but the sudden shock completely prostrated poor Antoinette; threw her at once into a fever, took away all her strength at once, and she has not yet recovered from it. Moreover we expect she will get strong pretty soon and then we are going East.

It is proposed to start as son as the fifth of May, and I shall very likely go clear on to New Hampshire with her; but may not be able to do more or go farther and must return here at one.

However, if I do I shall
Completed

intend to go East again in July or August to make a longer stay.

  It seems from letters from you that it has been quite sickly there about in Milo the past winter. More so very likely than it ever is here about. People here may not have as robust health as at the East; but still I doubt if in healthy localities here they are as sick. For two weeks past here has been very unseasonably - unusually cold. Two weeks ago the peach trees were beginning to bloom, and the various leaves to come out, and that is all that can be said of them now. It has been colder than any weather since the cold spell in January
Completed

Unseasonable weather is never healthy I expect; and as a consequence of this cold weather in season for warm weather, many here are complaining: through perhaps none are very sick.
I do not know when Charles will conclude to go East. This Winter Climate certainly agrees with him. He has I guess been better than usual through the winter. he is making Money, and it seems bad for him to leave before warm weather. At Wages, he can clear at least $2.00 per day above all expenses, as long as he will stay, which is probably better than he could do at home.
Completed

Probably his decision will depend upon what he hears can be done at Milo for help on his farm. He says there is little to do do there until haying. And if he could get the work done there for $20. or $26. per Month about as well as he could do it himself. And he could be earning 50. or 60 per Month here. it might be well for him to stay longer than till seed time.

 Little Mayo DuCoign DuCoign Mayo is getting on finely nowadays. his health seems to be very good. He creeps all about smartly, raises himself up as he pleases by Chair or any thing, and stand quite strong, but does not undertake to walk yet.
He has got teeth, two or three probably. It is hardly known
Completed

hardly known how many; he is so extremely careful of them. Even if his mouth were open his tongue is always put close to his lower jaw, and to try to touch them with the finger he resists most astonishingly, squirming like a young eel. It is said to be a fact that in spite of all the women; it was a full week after the spoon rattled daily against his new teeth before anyone ever saw them.
It is quite a comfort & convenience that in Antoinette's so poor health she has got so good a nurse for the little one.
You tell me to use my influence to put off the work here till another winter etc. Unfortunately my influence is otherwise engaged. I am a Man 'under Authority'. My directions are to have
Completed

the work done as rapidly as possible, at any expense. If I can do a peice of work now for ten thousand dollars, it is no difference if I know I could do it for five nest year. Never Mind, do it now. It is of great object to get the work done at once, and no expense is to be spared. Why I an trying to get it all done up & get clear away by July or August at any rate.

And I have Carte blanche for funds, if I will only get the work done.
 Antoinette was about visiting when she was taken sick, to you. She sends her love and will write when she gets stronger.

We both hope you will write to us often & much.

                                              Affectionately
                                                             I.S. & Ettie
                                                                   Metcalf
Completed

Dunbarton N.H.
                                                                                                                                  Sept 6. 1856

Dear Mother

                           Mayo is dead. I wrote to you that he was sick when I got here. The Disease proved to be Dysentery, of the most malignant kind. Nothing seemed to check it, or to do any good, and it reduced him rapidly.  He did not have his Clothes on after Monday, and not attempt to walk any then. In spite of all Medicine or Doctors could do the evacuations continued every few minutes, or an hour at the most, and of the worst character, worse to worse.  We had Dr. Carr of West Goffstown whom I knew and relied upon. I do not
Completed

do not kn ow but he did all that a Physician could do for him.
We did not entirely give up all hope until a few hours before death which took place, this morning, Saturday Morning, at fifteen minutes before four o clock.
Mayo was very patient in all his sickness and pain. He never complained without he was asked, always took his medecine, and did as he was told without a murmer.
Sometimes he said "Father, I want to be well." "Cant you give me some thing, Father, to make me well."
Oh it is a hard thing to see a little child suffer so. Several times in his delirium the last days, he would say, "Oh! I'm Afraid, I'm afraid to get down there." I told Nettie this morning that I did all my crying several days ago. I had a sort of feeling from the first
Completed

almost that he was not going to get well. I was with him all the time, and took about all the care of him, from Sunday morning, till he died at fifteen minutes before four oclock this morning. I was hardly out of his sight three minutes at any time till the afternoon before he died. Oh! Mother, he was not all I had to live for, by any means, but Oh, What a void it does make! He was my first born, my joy, my pride, my strength. I was too, prepared for it by days of expectation, while Nettie never felt that her glorious boy could die till last night. She, his Mother, she is almost crushed. Pray for us that we may feel that it is the Lord. He gave, and He hath taken away. Pray that we may feel that 'He doeth all things well".  
Mayo has been a comfort, and a joy, to us these years. We ought to bless the Giver for that.
Completed

We want to hear from you, what arrangements you & Samuel are making for the future; and how you are getting along these days.
We have got news from Elyria. They did not buy any place for us. The one we wanted was sold. But they have rented a house in the Village for us. I suppose likely we had better go out there, if you have any other way to get along; and I do not see why you cannot. Let Eliab move his folks up into Samuel's house. It will be convenient all around. Convenient about getting to their business together, save house rent for Eliab, besides getting his family into a healthier place
I want to hear what you do.
We shall probably go before a great while, if we go to Elyria

                                                                         Isaac
Completed

Dunbarton, Merrimack Co
                                                                                                Tuesday Sept. 16. 1856

Our Dear Mother

                        I wrote a few words in a letter I had previously begun to Samuel, on Saturday, to let you know that the hand of the Lord had again fallen heavy upon us.

Your letter so full of kindness and sympathy, though disclosing the additional affliction at Bangor, in the death of the Little Lucy, came to us at the same time.  Her death though I suppose was nothing at all unexpected by any one. But our children were so healthy, and strong.  Little Willie was never healthier stronger or fatter, than the Sabbath Mayo was buried, only one week before we laid him too away in the same quiet bed.
He as a very strong & healthy, as well as a very beautiful child. How he did run about the rooms on all fours, so fast you could hardly see his feet more, looking back over his shoulder to laugh, for all could but laugh to see him so; then springing up to push a chair about the room. Neither of them walked alone.
Completed

All who saw his corpse called him, a remarkably large bodied, & full chested child.

Monday 8th he had a little diarrhea, but was well. The Diarrhea grew worse, but we should not probably have been alarmed, if we had not just lost Mayo. Tuesday morning the Doctor came in and called it a severe teething diarrhea. His upper teeth were just coming through. Another Doctor since says it was Cholera Infantum. Wednesday he was very sick, & Wednesday night ~ 

Thursday morning he seemed very much exhausted, but we thought the disease had spent itself, and he was reviving. Friday morning he seemed really better. But towards night became very restless & uneasy, and grew more & more so. I suppose Dropsy, or some Effusion of Water or blood upon the brain commenced. Saturday Morning he fairly screamed for hours with pain & excitement of the brain, and before 9 a.m. had convulsions. 
He seemed to suffer extremely, and died very hard indeed.
He was sick so short time, his flesh had not gone at all. How beautiful the little corpse was; so plump & full, fresh & fair, clear and white as snow. It did not look like a dead body at all; but more like some beautiful Wax work
Completed

Little Willie was buried Sabbath at 5 P.M. (14th Sept
There was quite a crowd at the funeral.
Mayo's funeral was Sabbath forenoon Sept 7 at the church, a sermon by Mr. Eaton the Baptist Minister: and the whole large congregation followed to the grave. Every body knew him you seem and he had been at Church, as regularly as any body for Months.

  Neither Father or Mother Putnam begin to gain strength yet, are almost entirely helpless, require two watchers or nurses every night, but we hope they have got to the worst & will now recover, but they are so feeble, that it will be slowly.

Nettie was worn out & exhausted with fatigue & excitement all last week. Friday 12th, she was attacked with Dysentery, though she did not entirely give up until about the time little Willie died, but she has not been off her bed since.  The Doctors say her Dysentery is very mild, but must have its course or run of 8 or 10 days; and she is so entirely prostrated & exhausted that she will have to lie still a week or two. I take care of her myself. Asenath who is good as can be, and almost invaluable to us takes all the care of little Wilder both day & night, & has for a week or two. He has had Diarrhea & threatened with worse, but the Doctors think now it is checked, and that he will not be really sick any more.
Completed

My own health is good, and has been all the time; though both last week & week before I was somewhat worn out with care & watching.
I have now entirely recovered that.
Jennie had the Dysentery first, was sick 2 or 3 weeks, and was just recovering when the rest were taken sick. She has taken most of the care of Father, sometimes day & night both.
Asenath takes care of Wilder & orders the house.
Miss Hannah Marshall takes care of Mrs. Putnam.
And the neighbors are very kind indeed; some of them are in almost all the time to help, sometimes two or three of them all night.
We think the sick are all doing well now.

 When we shall go to Ohio, no one can tell.

Perhaps, Nettie will hardly feel like keeping house any where. How desolate any home will be to us. God has taken away the Olive Plants around our table, whose presence made every place so sunny and joyous to us. I fear we were too proud and happy in them.
I cannot write more.
You must write to us. We want to know of your health constantly.
I will try to write again soon. I have much to do.

                               Sincerely & Affectionately

With much love from Nettie and Isaac
Completed

Elyria, Lorain Co., Ohio Dec. 7. 1856

Dear Mother

   I wish you were out here to spend the Winter with us. You will have to come out before long at any rate. When Samuel comes west, next spring probably; you and Percie must come out and stay here. You know that now more of your children are here than in any other one place. So it is no more than fair that you should spend most of your time here. And it is really quite a comfortable place to live. We are finding ourselves very comfortably situated here. Do you know where the place is? It is right across the Common from the Presbyterian Church just beyong the Court house, the second house south of the Baptist Meeting house, Fronting on the Common so, with a side view towards the Beebe House & the DeWitt Block.  it is one of the pleasantest situations in the village. I will make you a little plan of the house but you will know all about it when you come: which must be before a great while.

I will make a sketch on the next page.
Completed

[Diagram of a house floor plan with three front steps leading to a porch, with door to inside stairs on right that lead down?, Parlor with 2 windows and measures15 X 16 on left, continuing on ground floor, Spicey? and Closet off Parlor in the Bedroom 15 X 17 with 3 windows and a porch off the bedroom viewed from one of the windows but no inside access. Beside the Bed Room is a Sitting Room, 14 X 15 with 3 windows. The Sitting Room enters through a door to the Parlor and has a small door to the bedroom and a door to the Dining Room behind it. There are stairs to the immediate left of the door to the Dining Room. The Dining Room measures !5 X 15 and has a porch to the right of it with three steps leading from the outside. The Dining Room has two windows, one on the right adjacent to the stairs and one on the far left. The Dining Room is separated by a door to the left to an area with a Bathroom measuring 6 X 9 with a Bath and Water Closet and window and it leads by a door to a Closet 4 X 9 which is accessible by a door to the Bedroom. The Closet has a window and a Wardrobe.  The Dining Room and Kitchen sit in the middle of the house at the back of it. The Kitchen (which has no measurements mentioned but appears in the diagram to be about 3/4 the size of the Dining Room, has 2 Windows, a Door to the outside on the right, a Pantry, a Sink and Pump, and a small  Closet?. The Pantry also has a window and a door leading to the Dining Room near its far left window.]
[Front Porch faces] Sidewalk and Middle Avenue Common
[top of page and left side of building with Bedroom]  Alley? Avenue?
[right of building with Sitting Room windows looking out to]   Garden etc.
That will give you perhaps some idea of it. The three West windows, towards the Avenue go down to the floor. The Parlor we do not use or furnish at all. On the Sitting Room, we have the carpet Samuel sent, and it looks finely, also Twenty dollar damask or trockatelle Curtains with gilt cornice & fittings. Instead of a sofa, we have got a pair of handsome divans, which with Melodeon, Whatnot Quartet, & chairs furnish it tolerably.   The bed room is the best room in the house, and we have got it comfortably furnished with damask curtains, large Mirror & Black Walnut Bedstead Bureau Commode etc.
In one corner of the BedRoom is a Marble top & bowl Washstand a fixture of the house, with both hot & cold water by a silver mounted fasset? head. And through a closet is a very convenient Bath Room with both hot and cold water at all times by simply turning a stop cock.
The rain water runs into a large tank in the back Chamber, before filling the large underground Cistern.
Completed

From the up chamber tank, pipes connect with a Copper Cylinder boiler, in the corner behind the kitchen stove,  which holds perhaps two or three barrels, and has an iron boiler pipe passing through the stove fire, so that the cylinder is kept full of hot water, which indeed does not get cool in all night. So the whole bath & hot water apparatus is no sort of trouble or inconvenience; and moreover is quite handy in the kitchen, where from a stop cock in the cylinder, hot water can be drawn at any time without the trouble of it on the stove.
Above stairs, are three large chambers, only one of which we use, and a little one over the stair way. Then there are two back Chambers, one of which the dutch girl uses, besides quite a garrett over the front of the house. So we use but a small part of the house; have only furnished two rooms below, & one upstairs.
The house is warmed by a furnace.
There are good sidewalks all the way from the Doctor's here, so that the women folks can walk in any weather. Anne makes it her rule {she says} to walk over here every day at least. But I guess she fails of it oftener than some of us do of going over there. 
It has been rainy to muddy weather much of the time since we have been there; but for a few days past very clear, bright, cold, & frozen.

 Nettie gets along admirably housekeeping, I think, though I tell her she is too "careful & troubled
Completed

"careful & troubled about many things." works & worries herself to have every thing just so nice & exact much more than is necessary with so small a family. She has got I guess pretty good Dutch girl, stout, willing, and able to do most every thing; if Nettie could be content not to see to every thing herself so much.
Monday morn. Dec. 8- 

~ Dear Mother - How glad I should be to have you all upon Isaac's suggestion, and come here with Percie. We are enjoying ourselves and well as we could possibly have expected. The thoughts will come sometimes how happy we should have been- how happy little Mayo and Willie would have been - and then I am astonished & grieved at myself that I should for one moment lose sight of their far greater bliss & joy in the bright home above.
 Little Wilder is ? and happy all day long. He had only four teeth - has taken three or four steps alone, grows fat and strong every day though I do not think him any stronger now than before he was sick. I am so glad Percie is so well - Raspberry leave and pumpkin bread seemed to be very Effectual. Isaac seems much better than when we came here. I did feel very anxious indeed about him. I feared he would be really very sick before he would be well. It was wonderful that he was not much sicker after so much care. Anna is just as good as can be - she comes over almost every day & Hattie & Libby come after, and altogether we have nice times. The black spot to me is the thought of Isaac's going away. I should really take great comfort in thinking of the winter if this did come up so often before me, and I do not mean to be unhappy about this either if he is only well. I should think Samuel's rooms must be very pleasant. We found a number of things nice & convenient that were not changed - spice box etc. Samuel is very thoughtful & kind.
Completed

Isaac
                                                                                                               Elyria Lorain Co. Ohio
                                                                                                                 Dec 30th, 1856

Dearest Mother

    How glad we were to get the first letter from you after you were sick! 

How wonderful rapidly you did get over your sickness! In one week from the time you were sickest, you were sitting up all day; and writing us a letter too. We have been much afraid you would be 'too smart', and get tired, or take cold, and not get on so fast for it. But we hope you are before now as strong & well as ever; though indeed it would be nothing at all strange of being sick so just at the beginning of winter, you should be in a degree delicate, and obliged to be unusually careful of fatigue or exposure till Spring. But you will be nicely smart by spring, say April, when you want to come out here with Samuel and Percy.  Then the balmy spring breezes of the Buckeye State will do you good all the more.
We just had a nice letter from Samuel
Completed

from Samuel, saying that he and Percy would probably come out in April.

 We are all in very good health, and enjoying quite a degree of comfort.

Ann is getting well rested from the fatigues of the Ladies Fair. Nettie is pretty smart, and quite 'housekeepry'  (Have you read Mrs. Stowe's "Dred"?) Jennie has been most sick ever since the Fair. (She was not well then, and got too much fatigued, She was one of the Saleswomen at the Fair) but she has got better now. As for me I am getting ever so fat & hearty. Judge De Witt says I have changed wonderfully since I have been out here, and that I look as well now as he has ever seen me.
Little Paul Wilder is fat & hearty as need be, as happy as a cricket, glad at nothing all day long, begins to try to talk, and to walk some; has six teeth & more coming. Our keeping house seems to work finely. All we seem to lack is to have you here with us, and to show us how to enjoy it. We are really quite comfortably situated.
Christmas Day. The Judge & all his family were here with us, including Miss Woodbury. Nettie calls it her first experience in getting up "A Dinner", and it is supposed she made
Completed

made out very well. At any rate, I call myself a judge of such things & I called the Oyster Soup good, and the Roast Turkey weighed most 20 lbs and was well cooked. As for the puddings & pies fruits & nuts, as they are not all eaten yet, I will not attempt to speak.

  I expect to go to Illinois next week, and when I shall get back I cannot yet tell. I suppose I ought to have gone before, perhaps, but somehow I have had no inclination to tear myself away.

Antoinette & I expect to unite with the Church here before I go away, and Jennie will probably do so at the same time. I hardly knew what to do about my case. I wrote to Mr. Sewall of Brownville some two months ago, hoping to get from him some statement of the case.
I thought I had lived about long enough in such a case, and that it was about time for me to belong somewhere. So I preferred to write with the Church here. Even although I might move away from here within six months.
Completed

Dear mother,

  Isaac has told you of the pleasure we all felt at your speedy recovery. I do hope you will be better than Ever now, and able in the Spring to come out here and make two households glad with your presence. You would enjoy seeing our only little one. He is so pleasant and happy and merry all day long. O how lonely should we be without him! He is standing by me now looking at the picture of two dogs and saying bow wow most energetically. He hardly talks now as much as little Willie did before he was sick. Anna was in a moment yesterday and two or three hours the day before. It is very pleasant to be near them, more so than I can tell. Hattie and Libbie came yesterday and took the baby to ride in his carraige. He laughs and crows at the very sight of them. They took him home with them yesterday and kept him two hours, I should think. It seemed strange enough to be without him so long. He feel perfectly at home there - has even lost all fear of the Dr. creeps up to him and laughs in his face, and talks to him very familiarly.
I try not to think anything about Isaac's going away. It will be trying enough when it comes. We do have such pleasant times together - Isaac reads loud a good deal, and I shall miss him. O so very, very much. But Anna is a dear comfort.

[left-hand side] Do please write soon- Your loving daughter Nettie.
Completed

Isaac
                                                Du Quoin, Perry Co. Illinois
                                                     Monday Jan 26 1857

My Dear Mother

  Your excellent letter of Jan 8th or 10th, I did not get until the 22d or 23d though it might have been here a few days before that, while I was away at Springfield, the Capital of the State. I spent about a week there watching the Legislature now in Session. Perhaps I may return before the Session closes. I want to see they do not do us any mischief by any action about cross or connecting lines of Rail Roads in this part of the State.
 I wrote a long letter to you since I came from Elyria; probably near the same time that you wrote to me.

Your letter gratified me much; but there were two things in it that I did not like very much. One was that Samuel intends to take Percy out to Minnesota with him. I had been hoping that he would leave him at Elyria;  while himself went on to Minnesota alone.

 My greater grievance is that you yourself think you will not come out with him. It will be a great disappointment to us. You know we never really had a home of our own before; and we feel quite important about it.

I do not believe I ever wanted, when a boy, to go home & see my Mother; to come and see me.
Completed

You speak of your being seventy years old as if it were a reason why you should not travel to see your children. I suppose the Threescore and ten of scripture is mentioned not at all as a limit, but as an average, Now we have an idea that our Mother is altogether above an average.  It will be generally conceded that you are really as smart, really no older than very many persons only 50 years old.  The number of years a person has lived has little to do with their capability for action or usefulness. Some are as mature at fifteen as others at twenty five. Some are worn out at Thirty five; others are in their full usefulness at Eighty-five. A friend of mine here named Hinckley whose Mother is over Ninety years old. Two of her sons are wealthy lawyers & business men in Westfield N. York. The Old Lady travels back and forth from Hartford Conn. to Westfield N.Y. several times a year; not unfrequently alone.

 However I guess you did not mention the Three score and ten as really a reason.
 But if you decide to remain in Maine this year on account of Albina & Almeda, of course we have only to submit, and wait a while longer - of we must until Fall.
 You have heard Nettie & I speak of the Du Quoine Female Seminary, which Miss Paine, the Teacher who boarded with us, was trying so much to make a beginning for. She went East and spent a year or so in begging for it; bought a small
Completed

farm with a house on it as a location for the Seminary; got out Teachers and commenced a school in the old house. 
And above all she kept begging.
Well they got a three story brick building for the first Wing of the great Seminary most up. In the mean time God is owning and blessing them in the highest success, success in comparison with which all other is as nothing. Their Seminary in the Old house numbers some forty young ladies in all. Yesterday five of them were admitted to the Presbyterian Church. Eight or nine others are called hopefully converted the present term; and the interest still continues unabated.  In fact, Miss Paine told me that but four or five of the whole number were now entirely unconcerned. 

 Now is not that worth nothing as a gleam of promise for this benighted land of Egypt? Another an ct of incorporation has just passed for a College to be located at Carbondale, a R.R. Station 18 miles South of Du Quoin. There is some hope for Egypt yet.

We had some excitement here last Friday night in the discovery of a kidnapping case. Some men found here with a Negro woman whom they were evidently  trying to get upon the cars and take to New Orleans to sell, a free woman.

The woman, who had hardly wit or knowledge enough, to distrust what they were going to do was rescued. But the Kidnappers
Completed

Kidnappers were suffered to escape. Though the presumption against them was positive, there did not seem to be legal proof.

  I wish you could have told me where in Illinois Samuel Metcalf is.
 Percy ought to go out doors every day. Might just as well as not; if his father could have arranged it to have him constantly along the fall. It would be very much better for him. Much less likely to have colds & croup. Why little Paul Wilder is out doors almost every day when it is not too very blustery. It does them good, even if it is cold; only wrap them up enough warmly.
  Have I not a cousin at Dubuque?

I wish you would write me his name.
Perhaps I would call upon him.

 I do not know when I shall go back to Elyria. Perhaps soon. But if I do I shall soon come back here. I have considerable to attend to here nowadays. My property here is getting valuable, and must be looked after & cared for.
 I hope you will write again soon and frequently
                      Sincerely Your
                               Affectionate Son
                                     Isaac S. Metcalf.

[upside down at bottom] I wish you would ask Eliab if he sent $30.00 to Palmer & Co. Marble Workers of Manchester,  according to my directions.  I fear there is some mistake. If they have not got it it will make trouble.
Completed

Ducoign Perry Co. Illinois
                                                                                          Feb. 15. 1857

My Dear mother

  I believe I have written to you twice since I left home in January. And I have received one letter from you. For it I was very much glad & obliged to you. In one respect however I hope you have changed your mind since then. You wrote then that you thought you should not come out to Elyria in the Spring with Samuel.

I hope you have changed your mind in this respect. I do not know but I wrote all I could think of before to persuade you to come out. I do think you should come out to us. Nettie and I shall be there this year; and after this it may be much more difficult to get to us. Now more of your children are in Elyria than in any other one place; and it is no more than fair that you should be with them. Do come. We are all relying upon it, and it will be too bad to disappoint us all.
Samuel too, I am afraid will not leave Percy at Elyria, unless you come too.
Completed

I did hope to get back to Elyria before this time, but I find a good deal here to attend to. This Property here is increasing in value, and needs attending to. I have been all the past week, surveying and laying off new lots for sale. This Du Quoin Property cost Mr. Keyes & myself about Thirty five hundred dollars ($3500.00) all told. We have already sold above Twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00) worth.  Sales mostly on time but on interest & amply secure. And I reckoned up the other day as estimate of the present value of the remainder, that now unsold - at Twenty four thousand dollars ($24,000.00) Making the whole amount $36,000.00, or more than tenfold the investment.  More, there is a part belonging to me alone besides. So that my whole property here in Illinois is certainly worth at least Twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00)  So upon the strength of this I have agreed to give Three hundred dollars towards building a Presbyterian Church here this season. Do you not think I am liberal, public spirited etc.?

 I should not do so much if there was not here a minister I like; of the Presbyterians here were not as yet few & weak in means; and if I did not regard it as of very great importance for the place to make a right
Completed

start in the right direction. In a few years it will be filled up with a great mass of a missing populations, and it will be much harder to give the right institutions the proper vantage ground. 
Perhaps in the end it will be to my advantage to be pretty liberal now.
The prospect now is that there will be 4 four churches built here this season coming. Presbyterian, Baptist, Methodist, Campbellites. The Campbellites & Baptists are the strongest. But the Presbyterians & Methodists are pretty earnest. The Baptists are to have a religious newspaper here soon. And probably there will soon be another, a secular paper too.

 I suppose both Nettie & Anna have written to you about coming out to Elyria this Spring. I hope they have made it plain that you had better come out.
  Did I not write to you about the prosperity of the Du Coign Female Seminary, of which you have heard Nettie & I speak. I believe I wrote you all about it.
   I am expecting the next news from Maine will be of Mr. Ryder's death. Nettie wrote me about the last news from him.
   Please write to us frequently & come to Elyria.
                                                             Your Son Isaac
Completed

Isaac March 25 / 57                           1857
                                                                                     Elyria, March 25

Dearest Mother

   Your letter came last night. We were all very glad to hear from you. But we were all rather disappointed at your final decision not to come out with Samuel. For we had not really given up the hope till now. But if it is fully decided we will not comment any more about it; but hope for some favorable way for you to come out early this fall, or in the summer. There may be some favorable way for you to come out early.

We especially hope so, for doubtless, We, Nettie and I will not stay here any longer than till next fall at any rate,
At any rate that is the probability.

 How comfortable we would all be here this Summer, if you could only be here. We are really very pleasantly situated here; nice comfortable house right in the village; every thing pleasant except that I have myself nothing to do here.
Completed

What I shall do is yet entirely uncertain. I have as yet nothing definite from the Iowa project.  The situation I have some prospect of is to be Chief Engineer of a long Rail Road Route through North Eastern Iowa and Southeastern Minnesota.
Probably several years employment, good salary, and good chances in every respect.
The prospects of my getting the situation are about equally balanced. If I do, we shall be permanently, or definitely settled out there as soon as it could be made convenient; and I could probably make it for Charles' interest to go there too, * James. 
As soon as, I can know & decide about it i will write to you all the particulars - both of position & prospects.

 We are taking lots of comfort nowadays while I am at home. Just now I am making garden some part of the time. Most every day, harness up the Doctor's bonny mare, and take the folks to ride. Nettie's dutch girl does very well indeed, appears to be, every thing she could ask for. Nettie's own health now appears very good - though she expects to be sick this summer. Little Wilder is very well, as
Completed

happy and roguish as ever you saw.
I do not know but he is as good as ever. Mayo was nearly, but he is much more roguish.
Anna's health I think is not good as it used to be. Her Stomach is out of order a good deal, digestion poor. I think she has dyspepsia some.
Doctor is busy in the Bank considerable, and does not like to ride much.
So the rest of us have to do it all.
We did expect Samuel here last of this week; but from your letter suppose he will not come till next week sometime.

  If you go to Milo to stay this Summer, or part of it, you must be very careful - for you know there is always so much to do there. You ought not to try to work even for your self or Percy at all. You are now Three score & ten and with Children like yours around you, you can well afford now to take the "Otium cum dignitate", a dignified ease.
  Better than to go to work yourself there you can hire a maid to wait upon you
Completed

and Percy. You deserve to have your serving woman the rest of your days surely. Really now, if you will do so nothing would afford me greater pleasure than to be permitted to pay the expense of it. Do now.
Shall I draw a check upon my Bankers in Bangor for you.
Let me see, what is the present style of the firm -- no Matter.

    To Furber & Metcalf
                                 Bangor Maine

Please pay to Anne M. Metcalf on her order, One hundred dollars and charge the same to my account

                                                                                                                I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Elyria Lorain Co. Ohio
                                                                                                                         May 31st 1857

Dearest Mother

 Your most excellent letter of May 35th arrived last night. We are all very much obliged to you for it, and all your good letters.

When Nettie wrote last the Doctor was sick I do not know whether they have written since. I think he has not been well since his fever last Fall. He got cold and was taken with Ague Chills, had them alternate days the first week, and then it was another week before he got out of doors. He is pretty well now has been out some all the past week, and increased in health & strength.

 We were very sorry to hear of your hard journey from Bangor to Milo. Think you ought to have had some easier method of travel, than the Old Stage Mud Wagon. It was a harder trip than from Bangor here.
We shall be anxious to hear how the other children get over the Rash.
Completed

Samuel was rather slack about writing. He arrived at St. Paul May 1st. Wrote to us on his return from Cottage Grove May 16. And then wrote only business, or simply. He liked Minnesota, Theodore was sick, and then about the new Rail Roads, and wanting me to come up there and get the Charge of the New Minnesota & Pacific R.R.d..  His letter came last Monday 25th. I was a good mind to start up there at once, perhaps shall ~ but expect to hear from him again very soon.  The Minn. & Pacific R.R.d. ~ 50 Minnesota Corporators  are the Directors for first year.  P.P. Furber, Samuel Stanchfield etc. are influential, and Samuel think I.S. Metcalf can be Chief Eng.
They want to make immediate Surveys.

  In the mean time I have been buying property here in Elyria.

Have bought the Bullock place, you probably do not remember it but I can describe it. On West Avenue - first Street running South this side of the Doctors, Corner of Washington House. It is one of the last houses up this Street, so it is some fifty rods or more south of Main St.
Completed

Most five acres of land running back to the West Branch River; fine evergreen grove on back end of lot, Most 300 young fruit trees growing on it, and a fine garden;  well under drained.

 House story & half, small but large enough for our family.  Possession first of Oct. I intend to make some changes, add to the Nursery BedRoom an addition much such as Samuel did to that Bangor House Put in a Furnace, BathRoom etc. 
 The New Elyria School House is now building up near there, and the tendency of Village improvement is like to be in that direction. So it will be increasing in value. I pay $2100.00 The Doctor calls it worth $3000.oo or more.
 I like Lucy Heywood & Anna Mayo for your Babies names very much.
  Albert Lee Connable does not live in DuBuque I judge. Name is not on the Directory there, and those who know such thing knew nothing of such name as a Dubuque name. as far as my inquiries extended.

Neither have I ever heard any thing of his sister, or her folks.
Ann hears occasionally from
Completed

The Zanesville people, - Sam Williams' children S.W. writes that his Father comes East last of June, and Olive & her husband this Fall.   No.

I have got a fine garden here, Peas, Tomatoes too almost ready to bloom. Lettuce large enough to East Plenty of Pie Plant, Corn, Beans, Beets, Onions, Tomatoes, Potatoes, Squashes, Melons etc. all growing finely.  The Season has been exceedingly backward - No warm weather until May 21sr.

Leaves did not come out at all till last Week etc.
The Doctor & Anna have, on account of his sickness put off their journey to Illinois till next fall.

  Please write often
         Affectionately
                Isaac S. Metcalf 

[right-hand side]  Isaac Elyria May 31 / 57

                               Milo
Completed

Elyria, Ohio. Aug. 8 1858

Dearest Mother

  Your letter came to hand yesterday; and we were all gladdened thereby.  I had been about writing to you for some days; and upon the strength of your letter will try to do it at once. I cannot perhaps answer your letter exactly, for Anna carried it off to show to the Judge.
 Anna's letter it seems you had not received when you wrote. I expect she, and perhaps all of us, have been a little remiss about writing of late; some of us will try to do so better in future.
  We are sort of dull here of late. Jenny went home last week. Emily was married a week ago. We got another girl before Emily left, whom we expected to like, but she was taken sick, spitting blood, I expect she danced too hard at Emily's wedding. Anna's 'Katy' is about sick upon the same grounds. So we have had no girl for almost a week: expect one tomorrow.
Then Nettie & I have both been about halfway sick. To begin with I had an awful boil on my leg. It absolutely crippled me for a week or more. I could hardly step at all. Then I had when rid of the boil, a week since, a slight attack of Cholera Morbus, such as I am subject to occasionally. And
Completed

following the Judge's advice, took after it a dose of "blueing." - blue pill - instead of my own usual prescription, a dose of Quinine ~ to stiffen me up.

  The Effect - I have felt as flat as fritters, & lazy as logs, ever since. Nettie has had a cold & cough for two or three weeks, but is getting over it I guess.
  Wilder & Charlie - well, where aren't they, and what dont they do? Charlie doesn't walk yet, but creeps on all fours just as Willie did; only his limbs move. Charlie lumbers about the house with the agility of a hippopotamus: he climbs up by Chairs etc. climbs down onto the door stop to go out doors.  and climbs up one step to go up stairs, and then sits down to rest & falls off.

About your making your home here with us Mother, of course, you must do exactly as you prefer about it. Whatever you really prefer, will be 'the best' -- will be, as you say, "duty."  But it has seemed to me, we could manage things so you would really prefer it here.  When you were here was no fair sample, we were just getting here, moving, getting arranged, hurried, vexed & troubled by the difficulty of getting any present money, for present pressing wants.  We expect to be, & are getting to be, perhaps slowing getting, leisurely, and comfortable.  We are not rightfully so poor, & harassed as we seemed when you were here.  There is now more than Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) due me on
Completed

Du Quoin Land Sales. It is seemed against possible alternate loss, and draws 10 per cent interest. The Balance unsold is probably worth $20,000.00  So you see we are certainly able to live comfortably; and intend to; just as we please.   Anna think you do not like to be 'dependent' even on your children; that you ought to have a purse of your own to use as you please. How would this do?  I will deposit a Thousand dollars for your use; or such a sum, in such a way. that the interest, one hundred a year, say $25.00 each Jan. April, July & Oct., shall be payable at Lorain Bank to your order, for your sole use & behoof, as long as you live. This would clothe you as you like, and leave a slight balance for J.B. as dear Joseph used to have it.  How would that suit you?  Do come, Mother!
And don't wait a year first either. You can go back there every year if you like. 
We intend to visit there frequently after we get arranged - most every year perhaps.

Nettie thinks I have abused Charlie in my reference to him. He is said to be a remarkably fine looking Child, but I think he exhibits more dignity than agility by far ~ couldn't well be otherwise with his substantial form.
 I wish you could see my Garden now. The Corn is 8 or 10 feet high. The Beet Carrots etc. absolutely quarrelling for room. Tomatoes are big as a small milkpan almost, but not yet beginning to ripen.
Completed

We have begun upon our Parlor. Got a Carpet down - a Brussells called very pretty. and got some pictures hung up. Marble table etc.; but money comes slow as yet; and we do things little by little here.
Our nice stone side walk is not built in from of this lots; though Mr. Murphy's is, and a handsome fence too; and a sidewalk away down on this side of the street. Elyria side walks show great changes this year.

 I was going to write another letter to Almeda, in answer to her excellent one which came with yours; but the fact is, I really have not spunk enough today

{Monday evening}
I intended to write some, but find it about enough these warm days, to do our work, and take care of the great baby. His upper gums are very badly swelled indeed, and he feels very fretful, with those, and the hear. I expected a girl today, but she has not come. Anna has been here a few moments - one of her hurried evenings, as usual. It is very busy getting Hattie ready to go away. Wilder says "come Charly, lets go like sixty." Where could he have heard such an Expression!  A few nights ago he began to cry bitterly in the middle of night, and we asked what the matter was  - Said he "my dear little brother is carried away out doors. He's dead and I never can see him any more" - We could not quiet him for a long time - He often speaks of Percy, and one day he was upstairs with me when I was cleaning after the joiners had fitted blinds to the windows, and he said "these men should'nt do so,' cause this is grandmother's room, & Percy's mom. They should'nt do so, should they ma' ma". We all wish you to come back very much, it if would be pleasant for you.
Completed

Elyria Lorain Co. Ohio
                                                                                              Oct. 3s 1858.

Dear Mother

 I believe we have got no letter from you, since I was there a month ago, and we begin - or rather continue to want to hear from you. Eliab has written once or twice about the sickness of their little ones. Wish you would write frequently; think you better some out here pretty soon. We are all pretty well;  especially the children who are as fat and hearty & stout as you may imagine. Charlie hardly goes alone much yet; though he gets up alone in the floor, & takes a few steps sometimes, but usually thinks it safer to keep a chair by him, which he lifts over a threshhold or any impediment, & goes on again.

Wilder goes to meeting some; but lately has cried once or twice, getting asleep & waking up cross. Perhaps we will not be able to have him go. But while we have two girls, he does not need to.
Completed

I wrote you that Old Mrs. Dolittle died before I got home. Mrs. Fitts has failed pretty fast since; probably will live but a very short time. Naomi is at the Doctors ever since the old lady's death, which releases Anna entirely.
Anna has a new, aged, & capable girl so she is very comfortably situated.
Nettie has a little girl, her girls' sister to take care of Charlie, which relieves her very much.
Last Thursday  we went over to Oberlin, visited at Dr. Dascombs', and heard Pres dl"? Finney preach his weekly lecture. When you are here again, I mean you shall go over to Oberlin occasionally; hear Mr. Finney, & know more of the people there. I like some of them much. Old Father Keep of Oberln preached for us last Sabbath while Mr. Wilbur was at Synod.

  I have been at work considerable since my return home in my Quarry  have got out lots of stone, some for side walks, but more other things, have not got my sidewalk built yet, but intend too.
Completed

There is, now a good side walk, much of the way of stone, most all the way from her to the Doctor's on this side of the Street.
The nice house building just below Mr. Mussey's. Most of the buildings in town in this part of the village. 
I forgot to say that the Doctor is hardly well lately, and fears that his Dyspepsia is getting to his lungs.
It has been delightful weather here since I returned; mild as early September all the time, no frost of any amount yet. only the tips of tender leaves touched at all yet.  The Corn which, planted the last of June many, six weeks ago, dispaired of, has ripened off fully & first rate.
The River down in our grove is so low that Nettie walked across on the stone the other day, and is as clear & transparent as pure spring water.

 It seems like Illinois to have corn & other crops all harvested before frost.  Something you never saw in Maine, Corn leaves & stalks all dead, withered & dried away, corn hard & dry, without any frost.
Completed

Mr. Rood has left & gone to New York Family about going; his business affairs in very bad shape, in default as Clerk of the Court a thousand or two, much of which, Mr. Crane, who is ill able, will have to pay as bondsman. Rumored defalcation in Mr. Wilbur's Salary, of which Rood was Treasurer. Mr. Rood Elder of Church. Wm Bradford & his Cleveland wife, and Lucy Bradford are propounded for admission to the Church.  This Son of Dea Bradford, you may remember, had been a little unsteady. He married East spring an heiress.
Elyria Ladies Sewing Circle lately sent a box valued over a hundred dollars to a Home Missionary. Propose now to make Mr. Wilbur a Life Member.

Mr. Wilbur preaches good sermons. I think improves more & more. 

Please come & help hear him.
Till then write often.

                                                      Sincerely
                                                                        Isaac
Completed

Elyria, Ohio, Oct 5 1858

Dear Mother

    I intended to write some letters as soon as I got home; but I got here lazy, and more over found considerable to do when I arrived, and so this is my first attempt at it.
When I go to Bangor, Eliab over? persuaded me to stay there till Wednesday. That made my visit at Dunbarton rather short. I arrived there at 10 P.M. Wednesday, and staid till 8 A.M. of Thursday. Got home Saturday. Found all well here: both the children still fatter & stouter than when I went away. Nettie had not been very well, the care of the heavy children was too much for her; and she had to get an other girl, a little one, to take care of Charlie for her. Anna & her folks are quite well I believe. Old Mrs. DeWitt died last week Tuesday and was buried on Friday. Mrs. Fitts I believe is thought to be failing, going gradually more weak & emaciated.
I do not know as there is any news here. Mrs. Lyman Knowles is selling out her Goods, and removing to New York. There has been no frost here yet. The Corn  late planted, is ripening off very nicely.
Completed

Charles

 I was glad to see you had fenced off the upper Intervale for Pasture. It would be a much better way to renovate more of it than to crop it with Oats, as you have some of it. No other land could bear so much of that as your intervale has. But I very much doubt whether any one who has so much so good land as you have can afford to spend time & money in clearing & breaking up that ? Knoll. You can hardly get a fair return for the outlay.

Sow? the brakes frequently; burn  it over and perhaps sow white clover seed. On that kind of soil, grass will in the long run overcome almost everything, non brakes?.

  I wish you could see my little Corn Patch now. No frost here yet, and the Ears, after the stalks are topped, are almost as high as my head. It was so tall & heavy I could not handle it the whole length.
  Hattie De Witt, Mother, passed her Examination comportulley; and likes Mr. Holyoke very much.
                                             Sincerely, Isaac
Completed

I.S.M. To Anna M.M.
May 1st 1859                                                                                  Elyria Lorain Co. Ohio

                                                                                                      Sabbath Eve. May 1st ' 59

Dear Mother

                      I wrote you some time ago of Nettie & sickness, commencing nearly five week's ago. She had a very severe time of it, suffered very much indeed; left breast burst in two place, and was lanced in two other places. It was so painful it reduced her very much; for nearly four weeks she could not stand alone. Last week she gained strength & got up smartly. Wednesday really began to walk; Thursday was all over the house & carried out doors. Friday rode out. Saturday put to rights various things that she thought sadly disordered during her long confinement.                          Over.
Completed

Sabbath Day; this beautiful May Day; fair, sunny, pleasant, above all previous days of the year.

                                                                       7 a.m.
                                                             May 1st 1859,

was born the - Eldest daughter, one month before the time; but very plump & fat, apparently hearty & healthy; said to especially resemble Charlie, who is called "good looking," and who is certainly good natured.
"Both Mother & Child appear to be going "very well."
Some suppose that a babe, born at such time & season, would naturally be called - "May."
Completed

Seems to me it is long since we have heard from you. Please to write often as you can.

We want to hear from you all there very frequently.
Weather here - curious
March very warm & Sunny - early.
April cold, wet, uncomfortable.

 Nothing seemed to grow for a Month except perhaps the grass & wheat,

April 29th Sudden change

 "    30th  first warm day for a Month.

May 1st____
In My Garden here hardly done anything yet, a little in March. Since then the weather has been so unpromising. and I have had so much to do, taking care of Nettie etc.
